36049:
### **Your Comprehensive Backstory**  

#### **Personal Background and Family Life**  
You were born in this country in the year 1997, making you 20 years old. You are male, currently single, and have no children. You live regularly in a household of four people, including yourself, and reside with your own parent(s). Your father was born in this country, belonging to the semi-skilled worker group (e.g., bricklayer, bus driver, cannery worker, carpenter, sheet metal worker, baker). Your mother was also born in this country, though your father was born in country 360. Your mother has completed primary education, and you have completed primary education as well.  

Family is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud. You or your family never went without enough food, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months. No one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, and you or your family never felt unsafe from crime in your home during that time.  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
You belong to the Muslim denomination, and religion is very important in your life. God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and you pray several times a day. You attend religious services once a month. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people rather than to follow religious norms and ceremonies.  

You completely disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You agree that religion is right when it conflicts with science. You do not believe in heaven, hell, or life after death. You completely disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political Views and Government Trust**  
You place your political views at position 10, the rightmost position on the political spectrum. You are not very interested in politics and are not a member of any political party. You have no confidence in parliament at all and are not satisfied at all with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You have a great deal of confidence in the government and quite a lot of confidence in the civil service, courts, and armed forces. You believe your country is completely democratic in how it is being governed today (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe votes are counted fairly fairly often in this country's elections, though you also believe voters are not often offered a genuine choice. You think TV news favors the governing party very often in elections.  

You strongly believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that the army taking over when the government is incompetent is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Economic and Work Perspectives**  
You belong to the lowest income group in your country but describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class. You are employed full-time (30 hours a week or more) and are not the chief wage earner in your household. Work is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You agree that work is a duty towards society.  

You strongly believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You agree that people who don’t work turn lazy. You strongly believe that competition is harmful (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You think it would be a good thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives.  

#### **Social and Cultural Attitudes**  
Friends are very important in your life, and you occasionally discuss political matters with them. You obtain information by talking with friends or colleagues daily. You trust people of another religion somewhat and do not mind having people of a different religion or race as neighbors. However, you do not trust people you meet for the first time very much, nor do you trust people you know very much. Generally, you feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

You would not like to have unmarried couples, homosexuals, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people who have AIDS as neighbors. You disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come here to work. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, provides asylum to political refugees, or leads to social conflict. You also disagree that immigration provides a better life for people from poor countries. You believe immigrants have a quite bad impact on the development of your country.  

#### **Security and Crime**  
You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons but have not avoided going out at night for the same reasons. You feel quite secure these days. Police or military interference with private life does not occur at all in your neighborhood. Racist behavior does not occur at all in your neighborhood, though alcohol consumption and street violence occur quite frequently. Robberies and drug sales do not occur frequently in your neighborhood.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from TV news and radio news daily, from your mobile phone daily, from the Internet daily, and from a daily newspaper monthly. You never obtain information from email. You have quite a lot of confidence in the press but do not have very much confidence in television.  

#### **International Views and Organizations**  
You do not have very much confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, or the International Criminal Court (in which you have no confidence at all). You believe the IMF headquarters are located in London. You have a great deal of confidence in the World Health Organization and quite a lot of confidence in environmental organizations.  

#### **Personal Values and Priorities**  
You consider hard work, good manners, independence, and a feeling of responsibility important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider imagination or religious faith important for children.  

You strongly believe that incomes should be made more equal (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, followed by seeing that people have more say about how things are done at their jobs and in their communities. You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as fair.  

You are very proud to be of your country's nationality and feel close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district. However, you do not feel very close to your continent.  

This is your story—rooted in faith, family, and firm convictions about the world around you.
96531:
### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in this country in the year 2000, making you 20 years old. You are male, currently single, and have no children. You live with your own parent(s) in a household of nine people, including yourself. Your family just got by during the past year, and you or your family sometimes went without enough food to eat in the last 12 months. You or your family often went without a cash income in the same period, though you rarely felt unsafe from crime in your home. Your standard of living is about the same as your parents’ when they were your age.  

Your father and mother were both born in country 716, though your mother was also born in this country. Your mother has no formal education or only early childhood education. You have completed primary education. You belong to the lowest income group in your country and describe yourself as part of the lower class. You are unemployed and not the chief wage earner in your household.  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Muslim denomination. You believe in God, heaven, and hell, and God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You pray several times a day and attend religious services once a week. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to other people.  

You strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You also strongly agree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You moderately agree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
Work is very important in your life. You strongly agree that work is a duty towards society and that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy. You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives.  

You strongly believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You also strongly believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly believe there should be greater incentives for individual effort (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe competition is harmful (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are not very interested in politics and are not a member of any political party. You place your political views at position 5 on the left-right scale (center position). You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, and you believe living in a country governed democratically is absolutely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). However, you believe your country is somewhat undemocratic in how it is being governed today (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

You strongly agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). However, you strongly agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do and that men make better business executives than women.  

You believe votes are not at all often counted fairly in this country's elections, and voters are not often offered a genuine choice. You never vote in national elections. You are not satisfied at all with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). Your opinion about society is that the entire way our society is organized must be radically changed by revolutionary action.  

#### **Views on Government and Security**  
You do not have very much confidence in the government, parliament, courts, or banks. You have quite a lot of confidence in the police, armed forces, and churches. You believe the government definitely should not have the right to monitor all e-mails and any other information exchanged on the Internet. However, you believe the government probably should have the right to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

You believe making sure this country has strong defense forces should be the second most important goal for the country over the next ten years. If it came to war, you would be willing to fight for your country. You are worried very much about a war involving your country.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
You do not trust people of another religion or nationality very much. You believe the government should prohibit people from other countries coming here to work. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants. You disagree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity, provides asylum to political refugees, or leads to social conflict. You also disagree that immigration provides a better life for people from poor countries.  

You find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies. You believe immigrants have neither a good nor bad impact on the development of your country. You disagree that immigration increases unemployment or the crime rate.  

#### **Social and Neighborhood Life**  
You live in a neighborhood where alcohol consumption and robberies occur quite frequently, and drug sales are also common in the streets. However, racist behavior, police or military interference with private life, and street violence do not occur frequently in your area.  

You do not trust your neighborhood at all and have avoided going out at night for security reasons. Still, no one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, and you have not been a victim either.  

#### **Personal Values and Ethics**  
You believe political violence, stealing property, violence against other people, terrorism, cheating on taxes, claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to, avoiding fares on public transport, prostitution, homosexuality, sex before marriage, casual sex, divorce, and euthanasia are never justified (all level 1 on a scale of 1-10). However, you believe parents beating children is always justified (level 10).  

You consider hard work and good manners important qualities for children to learn, but not imagination, independence, religious faith, or a feeling of responsibility.  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You never obtain information from email, the Internet, TV news, or daily newspapers. You obtain information from radio news less than monthly and from your mobile phone less than monthly. Instead, you get information by talking with friends or colleagues weekly.  

You have no confidence in the press at all and do not have very much confidence in television. You do not trust people you meet for the first time at all and generally need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
All things considered, you are completely dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are not very happy. Your state of health these days is fair.  

Despite your struggles, you remain quite proud of your country's nationality, though you do not feel close to your village, town, city, county, region, district, or continent. You believe protecting freedom of speech is most important for the country, and you strongly value democracy—even if you feel it is not fully realized in your homeland.

### **Your Background Story**

Over the past year, your family spent some savings, but you never went without enough food, a safe shelter, or a cash income. You also never felt unsafe from crime in your home.  

#### **Work and Economic Status**  
You are self-employed and belong to the second-highest income group in your country. Work is very important in your life, and you agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. However, you disagree that work is a duty toward society. You largely believe in greater incentives for individual effort, with minimal support for income equality (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You moderately believe that private ownership of business and industry should be increased, with limited support for government ownership (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You also largely believe that hard work usually brings a better life, with minimal attribution to luck and connections (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). Comparing your standard of living with your parents' at your age, you find it about the same.  

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You place yourself at the center of the political spectrum (position 5 on the left-right scale). You are somewhat interested in politics and occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You are a member of a political party, a labor union, a professional association, and a humanitarian or charitable organization—though you are not active in any of them. You are not a member of any other organizations, including women’s groups, self-help groups, or religious, art, or sports organizations.  

You believe your country is extremely democratic today (level 9 on a scale of 1-10) and that living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10). You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system and very bad to have a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections. You also feel it would be fairly bad to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections.  

You might attend a peaceful demonstration, join a strike, or contact a government official. You have signed a petition before, including an electronic one, and might encourage others to vote or take political action online. You believe voters are offered a genuine choice fairly often in elections, votes are counted fairly often, and opposition candidates are prevented from running fairly often. You consider having honest elections rather important.  

#### **Social and Cultural Beliefs**  
Friends are very important in your life, and you trust people you know personally somewhat, as well as those you meet for the first time. You trust people of another religion and nationality somewhat. You generally believe most people can be trusted, and you trust your neighborhood completely.  

You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you do not belong to any religious denomination or organization. Religion is not very important in your life, and God is very unimportant (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You never attend religious services or pray, and you do not believe in God, heaven, hell, or life after death.  

You strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples. You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different religion, race, or language, homosexuals, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Diversity**  
You believe immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, provides asylum to political refugees, and offers people from poor countries a better life. However, you also agree that immigration leads to social conflict. You think the government should let people come to work as long as jobs are available and disagree that employers should prioritize citizens over immigrants when jobs are scarce. You find it hard to say whether immigration increases unemployment or crime rates. Overall, you believe immigrants have neither a good nor bad impact on your country’s development.  

#### **Law, Order, and Human Rights**  
You believe there is a great deal of respect for individual human rights in your country today. Civil rights protecting people from state oppression are an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy to you (level 10). You strongly oppose government surveillance, believing it definitely should not monitor emails, collect information without consent, or keep people under video surveillance in public areas.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the police, courts, and civil service but no confidence in parliament, the press, television, or universities. You do not have very much confidence in the government, armed forces, NATO, the UN, the World Bank, the IMF, or major companies. However, you have quite a lot of confidence in environmental organizations, the WHO, the International Criminal Court, banks, and charitable organizations.  

You believe political violence, terrorism, violence against others, stealing, fare evasion, tax cheating, bribery, and parents beating children are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe euthanasia (level 9), homosexuality (level 9), casual sex (level 10), sex before marriage (level 10), and divorce (level 10) are almost always or always justified.  

#### **Science, Technology, and Progress**  
You strongly agree that science and technology make life healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 8) and that the world is better off because of them (level 8). You completely disagree that knowing about science is unimportant in daily life (level 1) and slightly disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 4). You disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science.  

You don’t mind if there was more emphasis on technology development. You obtain information daily from the Internet, weekly from TV news, radio news, and conversations with friends, monthly from a daily newspaper, and less than monthly from email.  

#### **Gender Equality and Social Values**  
You strongly disagree that men make better political leaders or business executives than women and that a university education is more important for boys than girls. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often and that equal rights for women are an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10). You neither agree nor disagree that a woman earning more than her husband causes problems.  

You consider good manners and hard work important qualities for children to learn but not responsibility, imagination, independence, or religious faith.  

#### **Economic and Social Priorities**  
You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important national goal, followed by progress toward a less impersonal, more humane society, and people having more say in their jobs and communities. You also believe fighting rising prices is most important, and you place a stable economy as a top priority.  

#### **Security and Global Concerns**  
You are not worried much about a terrorist attack or a war involving your country. If forced to choose, you prioritize freedom over both equality and security. You feel quite secure these days and are very satisfied with your life (level 9). Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy.  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You believe in democracy, individual freedoms, and the power of science, while maintaining a critical view of institutions and a strong commitment to social tolerance and equality. All in all, you describe your state of health as very good, and you feel very close to your local community, county, and region—though not to your continent.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal Demographics and Family Life**  
You were born in this country in 1988, making you 32 years old. You are male, currently single, and live in a household of just yourself. You do not live with your parents or in-laws, and you have no children. Your father was born in this country, as was your mother, though her origin is also listed as country 716. Your mother has completed upper secondary education, the same level you have attained. You describe yourself as belonging to the upper class and are the chief wage earner in your household, placing you in the sixth highest income group in your country.  

Family is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud. You or your family never went without enough food, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months, though your family did spend some savings during the past year. No one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year.  

#### **Religious Beliefs and Values**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Roman Catholic denomination. You believe in God, heaven, and hell, and you pray once a day. You attend religious services once a week and are a member of a church or religious organization, though not an active one. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than to follow religious norms and ceremonies. God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you trust people of another religion somewhat. You do not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors. However, you agree that religion is right when it conflicts with science, though you slightly disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
Work is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that work is a duty towards society. You also strongly believe that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You are self-employed and think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and strongly believe there should be greater incentives for individual effort (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe in competition (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and strongly believe that hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You somewhat equally believe in both private and government ownership, with a slight preference for private ownership (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You have no confidence in banks at all and not very much confidence in major companies.  

#### **Political Views and Governance**  
You place your political views at position 7 on the left-right scale, leaning moderately right. You are not a member of any political party and are not at all interested in politics, though you usually vote in national elections. You never discuss political matters with your friends and would never encourage others to take political action online.  

You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system in this country but believe your country is somewhat undemocratic in how it is governed today (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You are somewhat dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You believe votes are counted fairly very often, election officials are fair very often, and voters are offered a genuine choice very often in elections. You also believe opposition candidates are not at all often prevented from running.  

You strongly agree that having honest elections is very important and that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe civil rights protecting people from state oppression (level 10), women having the same rights as men (level 10), and people receiving state aid for unemployment (level 10) are absolutely essential for democracy. However, you believe the army taking over when the government is incompetent is not essential (level 1).  

You feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections but also feel it would be very good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. You moderately believe in both government and individual responsibility, with a slight preference for government responsibility (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Social and Moral Values**  
You consider good manners, a sense of responsibility, hard work, and religious faith important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider imagination or independence important. You strongly agree that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents.  

You believe political violence (level 1), stealing property (level 1), violence against others (level 1), cheating on taxes (level 1), accepting bribes (level 1), claiming government benefits fraudulently (level 1), avoiding public transport fares (level 1), prostitution (level 1), homosexuality (level 1), casual sex (level 1), sex before marriage (level 1), euthanasia (level 1), terrorism (level 1), parents beating children (level 1), and a man beating his wife (level 1) are never justified. You believe divorce is somewhat justified (level 6).  

You strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples and would not like to have homosexuals or drug addicts as neighbors. However, you do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different race, people who speak a different language, people with AIDS, or heavy drinkers as neighbors.  

#### **Immigration and National Identity**  
You are quite proud of your country's nationality and feel close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district, and your continent. You trust people of another nationality somewhat.  

About immigration, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, provides asylum to political refugees, and offers people from poor countries a better life. However, you also agree that immigration increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, and increases the crime rate. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should prioritize citizens over immigrants. You believe immigrants have neither a good nor bad impact on your country’s development.  

#### **Security and Crime**  
You do not feel very secure these days and have avoided carrying much money or going out at night for security reasons. Alcohol consumption, robberies, and drug sales occur quite frequently in your neighborhood, though racist behavior, street violence, and police or military interference with private life do not occur frequently. You trust your neighborhood completely but have no confidence in the police at all.  

You or your family rarely felt unsafe from crime in your home in the last 12 months, and you have not been a victim of crime in the past year. In your opinion, the fight against crime is the most important issue, followed by progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from TV news daily, your mobile phone daily, the Internet weekly, email weekly, a daily newspaper weekly, and radio news monthly. You never obtain information by talking with friends or colleagues. You do not have very much confidence in the press, television, or journalists, though you believe journalists provide fair coverage of elections very often and that TV news does not at all often favor the governing party.  

#### **International Views and Organizations**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, the World Health Organization, the International Criminal Court, and the churches. You have a great deal of confidence in universities and charitable or humanitarian organizations but not much confidence in environmental organizations, the civil service, parliament, the courts, or the armed forces.  

You believe international organizations should strongly prioritize being effective over being democratic (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You think the IMF headquarters are in Washington DC and that India is not a member of the UN Security Council.  

#### **Life Satisfaction and Future Goals**  
All things considered, you are somewhat dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 4 on a scale of 1-10), though taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. Your state of health is fair.  

You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years, followed by trying to make cities and countryside more beautiful. You think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
You strongly believe in democracy but see flaws in its current implementation in your country. You value security over freedom and prioritize hard work, family, and religious faith. While you are critical of many institutions, you maintain a strong sense of national pride and moral conviction. Your life is shaped by discipline, duty, and a cautious approach to trust, yet you remain hopeful for progress in both your personal life and society at large.

You were born in this country in the year 1942, making you 78 years old. You are male, currently married, and live in a household of two people, including yourself. You do not live with your parents or in-laws. You have three children, and family is very important in your life. One of your main goals has been to make your parents proud.  

Your spouse belongs to the sales group (e.g., sales manager, shop owner, shop assistant, insurance agent, buyer) and has completed upper secondary education. You are the chief wage earner in your household, and your family saved money during the past year. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and the third lowest income group in your country. Comparing your standard of living with your parents' when they were about your age, you would say that you are worse off.  

Your father was born in country 276 and belonged to the skilled worker group (e.g., foreman, motor mechanic, printer, seamstress, tool and die maker, electrician). He was an immigrant to this country. Your mother was born in country 40, is an immigrant to this country, and has completed upper secondary education.  

#### **Religious Beliefs and Values**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Protestant denomination. You believe in God, heaven, and hell. God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one. You pray several times a day and attend religious services once a week. You are actively involved in a church or religious organization.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of following religious norms and ceremonies. You agree that religion is right when it conflicts with science. You strongly agree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). However, you also strongly agree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is moderately better off because of science and technology (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You place your political views at position 8 on the left-right scale (leaning strongly right). You are not a member of any political party, women’s group, labor union, professional association, or any other type of organization. You are somewhat interested in politics and occasionally discuss political matters with your friends. You always vote in national elections and have encouraged others to vote before.  

You believe votes are counted fairly very often in this country's elections, and you believe election officials are fair very often. You believe voters are offered a genuine choice fairly often in elections and that opposition candidates are not often prevented from running. You believe voters are not at all often threatened with violence at the polls. However, you believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often, and you think journalists do not often provide fair coverage of elections.  

You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country. You believe living in a country governed democratically is of very high importance to you (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You believe your country is fairly democratic in how it is being governed today (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You are satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe having honest elections is very important for you. You also believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is mostly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You somewhat believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves, with some emphasis on government responsibility (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Economic and Social Views**  
You somewhat believe in both private and government ownership, with a slight preference for private ownership (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You believe fighting rising prices is most important for the country, and you think a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years. In your opinion, a stable economy is most important.  

You somewhat believe that hard work doesn't generally bring success—it's more a matter of luck and connections, though hard work has some importance (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You consider hard work, good manners, and a feeling of responsibility important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider imagination, independence, or religious faith important qualities for children.  

You disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. You disagree that on the whole, men make better business executives or political leaders than women do. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often in this country. You also believe that women having the same rights as men is mostly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
You believe immigrants have a very bad impact on the development of your country. You think the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come here to work. However, you agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, strengthens cultural diversity, and offers people from poor countries a better life. You find it hard to say whether immigration leads to social conflict or increases unemployment.  

You do not trust people of another religion very much, but you do not mind having people of a different religion, race, or language as neighbors. You trust people of another nationality somewhat. You trust people you know personally completely, but you do not trust people you meet for the first time very much. Generally speaking, you would say that you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

#### **Security and Safety**  
You have avoided carrying much money and going out at night for security reasons. However, you feel quite secure these days. Police or military interference with private life does not occur at all in your neighborhood. Racist behavior, robberies, street violence, and fights do not occur at all in your neighborhood. Drug sales and alcohol consumption in the streets do not occur frequently.  

No one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, and you have not been a victim either. You or your family never felt unsafe from crime in your home, never went without enough food to eat, never went without a safe shelter, and never went without a cash income in the last 12 months.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from your mobile phone and the Internet daily. You obtain information from TV news daily but from email, radio news, and daily newspapers less than monthly. You obtain information by talking with friends or colleagues weekly. You do not have very much confidence in the press, television, or major companies.  

#### **Views on Violence and Moral Justifications**  
You believe political violence is almost never justified (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe violence against other people is almost never justified (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe terrorism as a political, ideological, or religious means is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe stealing property, claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled, a man beating his wife, parents beating children, and someone accepting a bribe are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe avoiding a fare on public transport is almost never justified (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe homosexuality, euthanasia, and having casual sex are almost never justified (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe sex before marriage is usually not justified (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You believe divorce and prostitution are somewhat not justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You believe cheating on taxes if you have a chance is rarely justified (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **International and Organizational Trust**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the civil service, the government, the International Criminal Court, parliament, the courts, the armed forces, banks, universities, and the churches.  

You do not have very much confidence in the United Nations, environmental organizations, the World Health Organization, charitable or humanitarian organizations, the International Monetary Fund, or the press.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You are very proud to be of your country's nationality and feel close to your village, town, or city, your county, region, or district, and your continent.  

Of course, we all hope that there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country. About a war involving your country, you are not worried at all. About a terrorist attack, you are not worried much.  

You might attend a peaceful demonstration, might join a boycott, and might sign an electronic petition (but have not done so yet). You have signed a petition before. However, you would never join a strike, never organize political activities, events, or protests online, and would never contact a government official.  

You believe in freedom over equality and freedom over security. If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider freedom more important. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider freedom more important.  

You believe there is a great deal of respect for individual human rights nowadays in your country. You believe that people obeying their rulers is mostly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that people receiving state aid for unemployment is mostly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). However, you believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression, governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor, and religious authorities ultimately interpreting the laws are slightly not essential as characteristics of democracy (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

You strongly agree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology.  

You disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples, but you do not mind having homosexuals as neighbors. You do not mind having unmarried couples living together as neighbors or people who have AIDS as neighbors. However, you would not like to have heavy drinkers or drug addicts as neighbors.  

Work is not very important in your life, and you don’t mind if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. However, you agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time, and that work is a duty towards society. Leisure time is rather important in your life.  

You strongly agree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

This is your life—rooted in faith, family, and a strong sense of national pride, shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

You believe political violence, stealing property, violence against others, terrorism, prostitution, homosexuality, sex before marriage, casual sex, a man beating his wife, parents beating children, and accepting bribes are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe divorce, euthanasia, and claiming government benefits fraudulently are almost never justified (level 2).  

You strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples and would not like to have homosexuals, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts as neighbors. However, you do not mind having unmarried couples or people with AIDS as neighbors.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from TV news, radio news, and the Internet daily, from a daily newspaper daily, from email monthly, and by talking with friends or colleagues weekly. You believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often in elections.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are somewhat dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 4 on a scale of 1-10), but taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. You feel quite secure these days, and no one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year.  

You believe in a balance between government responsibility and individual responsibility, with a slight preference for individual responsibility (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is mostly essential for democracy (level 8).  

Ultimately, you value security over freedom, equality over freedom, and a stable economy above all else. You trust your neighborhood somewhat and people you know personally somewhat, but you generally believe you need to be very careful in dealing with people.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in this country in 1972, making you 45 years old. You are male, currently divorced, and live in a household with one other person—yourself being the chief wage earner. You have two children, and family is very important in your life. One of your main goals has been to make your parents proud, and you strongly believe that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents.  

Your father was born in this country and belonged to the semi-skilled worker group (e.g., bricklayer, bus driver, carpenter). Your mother, however, was born in country 380 and is an immigrant. You describe yourself as belonging to the working class and are in the second lowest income group in your country. Comparing your standard of living to your parents’ at your age, you find it about the same.  

Over the past year, your family spent savings and borrowed money, and you sometimes went without a cash income. However, you never went without enough food or a safe shelter, nor did you or your family feel unsafe from crime at home. No one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year.  

#### **Beliefs and Values**  
You believe in God, and God is moderately important in your life (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). However, religion itself is not very important to you, and you never or practically never attend religious services or pray. You do not belong to any religious denomination or church. You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one and believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow norms and ceremonies.  

You do not believe in heaven, hell, or life after death. You disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science and moderately disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You slightly agree that science and technology make life healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 6) and believe the world is much better off because of them (level 8).  

You consider hard work, good manners, and a sense of responsibility important qualities for children to learn, but not imagination, independence, or religious faith.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are somewhat interested in politics and occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You describe yourself as neutral in political orientation and are not a member of any political party. You strongly believe in democracy, feeling it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system and that living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10). You believe votes are counted fairly often in elections, and having honest elections is very important. However, you are not satisfied at all with how the political system is functioning in your country (level 1).  

You believe in gradual societal improvement through reforms. You strongly agree that incomes should be made more equal (level 1) and that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is mostly essential for democracy (level 8). You also believe the state making incomes equal is mostly essential (level 8). You moderately believe private ownership of business and industry should be increased, with limited government ownership (level 3).  

You feel it would be very bad to have a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections or a system governed by religious law without political parties. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often and disagree that men make better political leaders or business executives than women.  

#### **Views on Immigration and National Identity**  
You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district—but not your continent. You do not trust people of another nationality or religion very much.  

You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners coming to work here. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, or provides asylum to political refugees (you find it hard to say on this last point). You agree that immigration increases unemployment, social conflict, and crime, but also that it offers people from poor countries a better life. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should prioritize citizens over immigrants.  

#### **Security and Governance**  
You worry a good deal about a terrorist attack or a war involving your country. You believe the government probably should have the right to monitor all emails and internet exchanges and definitely should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas—though you think it probably should not collect information about anyone without their knowledge.  

You have no confidence in parliament, banks, the World Bank, or the International Monetary Fund at all. You also have little confidence in the government, courts, United Nations, NATO, International Criminal Court, press, television, major companies, and churches. However, you have quite a lot of confidence in the police, armed forces, civil service, universities, World Health Organization, and environmental and charitable organizations.  

#### **Work and Lifestyle**  
Work is very important in your life, and you agree it is a duty toward society. You also believe work should always come first, even if it means less spare time—though leisure time is rather important to you as well. You think placing less importance on work would be a bad thing.  

You are self-employed and moderately believe people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves, with some government support (level 7). You largely believe hard work usually brings a better life (level 2) and that competition is good (level 2).  

#### **Social and Moral Stances**  
You believe political violence, stealing property, violence against others, terrorism, parents beating children, a man beating his wife, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, fare evasion, and claiming undeserved government benefits are never justified (all level 1). You believe casual sex is often justified (level 8), sex before marriage almost always (level 9), divorce often (level 8), prostitution somewhat (level 6), and homosexuality somewhat (level 6).  

You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different race, religion, or language as neighbors. However, you would not like to have homosexuals, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors.  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You obtain information from TV and radio news weekly, from talking with friends or colleagues weekly, and from email, mobile phones, the Internet, and daily newspapers less than monthly. You do not have much confidence in the press or television but believe TV news does not often favor the governing party in elections.  

#### **Civic Engagement**  
You always vote in national elections and might encourage others to vote. You have signed a petition before and might sign an electronic one in the future. You might attend a peaceful demonstration or join a boycott but would never join a strike or organize political activities online. You might contact a government official but would never encourage others to take political action online.  

#### **Neighborhood and Safety**  
Police or military interference with private life does not occur at all in your neighborhood, nor does racist behavior. Robberies and street violence are infrequent, but drug sales occur quite frequently. You have avoided going out at night for security reasons but have not avoided carrying money. You do not feel very secure these days but trust your neighborhood somewhat.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are moderately satisfied with life (level 7) and describe yourself as rather happy. Your state of health is good, and you believe progress toward a less impersonal, more humane society is the second most important goal—after a stable economy, which you consider most important. A high level of economic growth is your top priority for the country, followed by strong defense forces.  

You believe in freedom over equality and security, and you trust people you know personally somewhat—but generally, you feel you must be very careful in dealing with others.

However, your family saved money during the past year, and you belong to the second-highest income group in your country, describing yourself as upper middle class.  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
You belong to the Roman Catholic denomination, and religion is rather important in your life. You believe in God, heaven, and life after death, though you do not believe in hell. God is somewhat important in your life (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), and you pray once a day while attending religious services once a month. You strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right and that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people rather than to follow religious norms and ceremonies. You disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one, though you do not trust people of another religion at all. You also do not trust people of another nationality at all or people you meet for the first time at all. Generally, you feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You place your political views at position 7 on the left-right scale (leaning moderately right) and are somewhat interested in politics. You are a member of a political party but are not active, and you would vote for another party if there were a national election tomorrow. You always vote in national elections and believe votes are counted fairly very often, though you think election officials are not at all often fair and that opposition candidates are prevented from running very often.  

You feel it would be very bad to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country and would prefer a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. You also feel it would be fairly good to have a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections, or to have experts, not government, make decisions for the country. You believe your country is somewhat democratic in how it is governed today (level 6 on a scale of 1-10) and are satisfied with how the political system is functioning (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe political violence is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), and you would never attend a peaceful demonstration, join a strike, sign a petition, encourage others to vote, or organize political activities online. You occasionally discuss political matters with friends, obtaining information from talking with them weekly, though you obtain information from email, mobile phones, radio news, and the Internet less than monthly. You get daily information from newspapers and weekly from TV news.  

#### **Economic and Work Perspectives**  
You are employed full-time (30 hours a week or more) but are not the chief wage earner in your household. Work is not very important in your life, and you don’t mind if there was less importance placed on work. You moderately believe that competition is harmful (level 8 on a scale of 1-10) and largely think that hard work doesn’t generally bring success—it’s more a matter of luck and connections (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

You agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women and that on the whole, men make better business executives and political leaders than women. However, you disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it causes problems or that when a mother works, the children suffer. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often in this country but also think that women having the same rights as men is slightly not essential for democracy (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Views on Immigration and Society**  
You believe the government should let anyone come who wants to work in this country, though you find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, or offers a better life to people from poor countries. You agree that immigration increases the crime rate and leads to social conflict but disagree that employers should prioritize citizens over immigrants when jobs are scarce.  

You believe immigrants have a quite good impact on your country’s development. You do not mind having people of a different race, religion, or language as neighbors, nor do you mind unmarried couples or homosexuals living nearby. However, you would not like to have heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors.  

#### **Security and Neighborhood Concerns**  
You do not feel very secure these days and have avoided carrying much money or going out at night for security reasons. Police or military interference with private life occurs very frequently in your neighborhood, along with racist behavior, robberies, alcohol consumption, drug sales, and street violence. Despite this, you trust your neighborhood somewhat and have rarely felt unsafe from crime at home in the past year. No one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year, though you yourself have.  

#### **Trust in Institutions**  
You have no confidence in the civil service, banks, churches, universities, the International Criminal Court, the World Health Organization, the International Monetary Fund, or charitable organizations at all. You do not have very much confidence in the government, parliament, police, courts, press, television, United Nations, NATO, World Bank, major companies, or environmental organizations.  

#### **Values and Priorities**  
If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider freedom more important, but if choosing between freedom and security, you would prioritize security. You believe in a high level of economic growth as the most important goal for the country, followed by people having more say in their jobs and communities. You also believe giving people more say in government decisions is most important.  

You consider good manners, responsibility, and independence important qualities for children to learn but do not value hard work, imagination, or religious faith for them. Leisure time is very important in your life, and friends are rather important.  

All things considered, you are moderately satisfied with your life (level 7 on a scale of 1-10) and describe yourself as rather happy. You believe the world is moderately better off because of science and technology (level 7) but moderately agree that science is not very important in your daily life (level 7).  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
You believe in gradual societal improvement through reforms and think our society must be changed this way. You feel very close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district, but do not feel close at all to your continent. Despite your distrust in many institutions and people, you hold firm to your religious and moral convictions, shaping the way you view the world and your place in it.

You or your family also often felt unsafe from crime in your home in the past year, and a member of your family has been the victim of a crime in the same period.  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you attend religious services more than once a week. You pray several times a day, and God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe in God and heaven but do not believe in hell or life after death. You do not belong to any religious denomination, and you disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of following religious norms and ceremonies. You completely agree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), yet you also completely agree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science.  

You hold strong moral convictions, believing that the following are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10):  
- Political violence  
- Stealing property  
- A man beating his wife  
- Parents beating children  
- Casual sex  
- Sex before marriage  
- Homosexuality  
- Prostitution  
- Euthanasia  
- Terrorism as a political, ideological, or religious means  
- Violence against other people  
- Divorce  
- Claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled  
- Cheating on taxes if you have a chance  
- Someone accepting a bribe in the course of their duties  
- Avoiding a fare on public transport  

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You place your political views at position 10, the rightmost position on the political spectrum. You are very interested in politics and always vote in national elections, though you believe votes are not often counted fairly in this country's elections. You are a member of a political party but are not active, and you are not satisfied at all with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe your country is not at all democratic in how it is being governed today (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country and believe that living in a country governed democratically is absolutely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). However, you also feel it would be very bad to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections or a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections.  

You believe the following are absolutely essential characteristics of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10):  
- People receiving state aid for unemployment  
- Civil rights protecting people from state oppression  
- Women having the same rights as men  
- Governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor  
- People choosing their leaders in free elections  

You believe that the following are not essential characteristics of democracy (level 1 on a scale of 1-10):  
- The army taking over when the government is incompetent  
- Religious authorities ultimately interpreting the laws  
- The state making people's incomes equal  
- People obeying their rulers  

You occasionally discuss political matters with your friends and might attend a peaceful demonstration, join a boycott, or sign a petition. You have signed an electronic petition before and might encourage others to vote, though you would never organize political activities, events, or protests online. You might contact a government official and might join a strike.  

#### **Economic and Work Perspectives**  
Work is very important in your life, and you are employed full-time (30 hours a week or more). You strongly believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and that competition is good (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You agree that work is a duty towards society and that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time.  

You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You strongly believe there should be greater incentives for individual effort (level 10 on a scale of 1-10) and strongly believe that private ownership of business and industry should be increased (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe most business executives and civil service providers are involved in corruption, though you believe few journalists and media people are corrupt. You have no confidence in the government, parliament, or civil service at all.  

#### **Social and Cultural Attitudes**  
Friends are very important in your life, and you trust people you know personally completely. You trust people you meet for the first time somewhat, as well as people of another religion or nationality. You do not mind having people of a different religion, race, or language as neighbors, nor do you mind having unmarried couples, homosexuals, heavy drinkers, or people with AIDS as neighbors. However, you would not like to have drug addicts as neighbors.  

You disagree that people who don’t work turn lazy and disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. You strongly disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. However, you agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do and that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems.  

You consider the following qualities important for children to learn:  
- Good manners  
- Feeling of responsibility  
- Hard work  
- Religious faith  

You do not consider imagination or independence important qualities for children to learn.  

#### **Security and Safety Concerns**  
You have avoided carrying much money and going out at night for security reasons. Robberies occur very frequently in your neighborhood, though street violence and fights, alcohol consumption, drug sales, and racist behavior do not occur frequently. Police or military interference with private life also does not occur frequently in your neighborhood.  

You are worried very much about a terrorist attack and a war involving your country. If it came to war, you would be willing to fight for your country. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information daily from:  
- Email  
- Your mobile phone  
- TV news  
- A daily newspaper  
- The Internet  
- Radio news  
- Talking with friends or colleagues  

You have a great deal of confidence in television but do not have very much confidence in the press. You believe TV news favors the governing party very often in this country's elections.  

#### **Immigration and Global Perspectives**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. You agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity and offers people from poor countries a better life, but you also agree that immigration leads to social conflict. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies or increases unemployment.  

You find it hard to say whether immigration increases the crime rate. You believe immigrants have neither a good nor bad impact on the development of your country. You agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants.  

#### **International Views and Organizations**  
You have a great deal of confidence in the United Nations and quite a lot of confidence in the World Bank and the World Health Organization. However, you do not have very much confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the International Monetary Fund, the International Criminal Court, or the armed forces.  

You believe international organizations should strongly prioritize being effective over being democratic (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe India is not a member of the United Nations Security Council.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). However, taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. You feel very secure these days, though you describe your state of health as fair.  

You believe the world is a lot better off because of science and technology (level 10 on a scale of 1-10) and think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology. In your opinion, progress toward a society in which ideas count more than money is the second most important, while a stable economy is most important.  

You strongly believe that government should take more responsibility to ensure that everyone is provided for (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms.  

You trust your neighborhood completely, though you do not feel very close to your village, town, city, county, region, district, or continent.  

This is your story—shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

Your mother completed post-secondary non-tertiary education. You hold a Master's degree or equivalent and are employed full-time (30 hours a week or more).  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Protestant denomination. God is extremely important to you (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), and you pray several times a day. You believe in God, heaven, hell, and life after death. You attend religious services once a week. You agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, though you trust people of another religion somewhat and do not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors.
