However, you also very strongly agree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 9 on a scale of 1-10) and believe the world is greatly better off because of science and technology (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

You strongly disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You consider hard work, independence, and a feeling of responsibility important qualities for children to learn, but you do not consider good manners, imagination, or religious faith important for them.  

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You place your political views at position 6 on the left-right scale (leaning slightly right). You are a member of a political party but are not active, and you are somewhat interested in politics. You occasionally discuss political matters with your friends. You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country and believe your country is extremely democratic in how it is being governed today (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You are extremely satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe votes are counted fairly very often in this country's elections, voters are offered a genuine choice fairly often, and election officials are fair fairly often. However, you also believe opposition candidates are prevented from running fairly often, voters are threatened with violence at the polls fairly often, and TV news favors the governing party very often. You believe having honest elections is rather important for you.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the government, the United Nations, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the International Criminal Court, the civil service, banks, major companies, the World Health Organization, charitable or humanitarian organizations, and universities. However, you do not have very much confidence in the World Bank, the press, television, parliament, the armed forces, the churches, the International Monetary Fund, or the police.  

You have attended peaceful demonstrations before, signed a petition, and signed an electronic petition. You might join a boycott or a strike, encourage others to vote, or organize political activities online (though you have not done so yet). You might encourage others to take political action online but have not done so yet. You always vote in national elections.  

#### **Social and Economic Views**  
You strongly believe that government should take more responsibility to ensure that everyone is provided for (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You largely believe that incomes should be made more equal, with minimal support for individual incentives (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You largely believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased, with minimal support for private ownership (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is very essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that the state making people's incomes equal is mostly essential (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that people receiving state aid for unemployment is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You agree that people who don’t work turn lazy. Work is very important in your life, and you agree that work is a duty towards society and should always come first, even if it means less spare time. Leisure time is rather important to you, but you don’t mind if there was less importance placed on work in our lives.  

#### **Views on Gender, Family, and Society**  
You agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do and that men make better business executives than women. You believe women do not often have equal opportunities to run for public office in this country. You strongly agree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer and that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women.  

You neither agree nor disagree that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems. You agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples, though you would not like to have homosexuals as neighbors.  

Family is very important in your life, and friends are very important as well. You agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You strongly agree that it is a duty towards society to have children. You neither agree nor disagree that adult children have the duty to provide long-term care for their parents.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Diversity**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, and provides asylum to political refugees. However, you also believe that immigrants have a quite bad impact on the development of your country and that immigration increases unemployment. You disagree that immigration leads to social conflict.  

You find it hard to say whether immigration increases the crime rate or whether immigration offers a better life to people from poor countries. You disagree that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants.  

#### **Security, Crime, and Justice**  
You have not avoided carrying money for security reasons, though you have avoided going out at night for security reasons. You or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months. You or your family never felt unsafe from crime in your home in the past year, and no one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year.  

You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, and in your opinion, the fight against crime is most important. You believe there is fairly much respect for individual human rights nowadays in your country.  

You believe civil rights protecting people from state oppression is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the government probably should not have the right to monitor all e-mails and any other information exchanged on the Internet but probably should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas. You believe the government probably should not have the right to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

Police or military interference with private life does not occur at all in your neighborhood. Racist behavior, robberies, drug sales, and street violence do not occur frequently in your neighborhood, though alcohol consumption in the streets occurs quite frequently.  

#### **Views on Violence and Justification of Actions**  
You believe political violence is always justified (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe violence against other people is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You believe a man beating his wife is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), and parents beating children is often justified (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe terrorism as a political, ideological, or religious means is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). Of course, we all hope that there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.  

You believe stealing property is often justified (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), cheating on taxes if you have a chance is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is always justified (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and someone accepting a bribe in the course of their duties is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe avoiding a fare on public transport is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), having casual sex is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), sex before marriage is often justified (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), prostitution is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), euthanasia is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), and divorce is always justified (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe homosexuality is rarely justified (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **International and Global Perspectives**  
You feel close to your continent and to your village, town, or city, but you do not feel very close to your county, region, or district. You are quite proud to be of your country's nationality.  

You believe India is not a member of the United Nations Security Council and that the IMF headquarters are located in Geneva. You believe international organizations should very much prioritize being democratic over being effective (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Life Satisfaction and Future Aspirations**  
All things considered, you are very satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as very good. You feel quite secure these days.  

In your opinion, progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is the second most important, and seeing that people have more say about how things are done at their jobs and in their communities should be the second most important goal for the country over the next ten years. You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years.  

You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology. Your opinion about society is that our society must be gradually improved by reforms.  

### **Final Thoughts**  
You are a complex individual with strong convictions, deeply rooted in your faith, national pride, and a mix of progressive and conservative values. You value democracy, equality, and security, yet you hold some controversial justifications for violence and corruption. Your life is structured around work, family, and religion, and you engage with the world through a mix of trust and skepticism toward institutions. Despite contradictions in your beliefs, you are content with your life and optimistic about the future.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal Demographics and Family Life**  
You were born in this country in 1987, making you 30 years old. You are male, currently single, and have no children. You live with your own parent(s) in a household of three people, including yourself. Your father was born in country 554 and is an immigrant to this country, belonging to the service group (e.g., restaurant owner, police officer, waitress, barber, caretaker). Your mother was born in country 36 but also in this country, and she holds a Bachelor's degree or equivalent.  

You describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class and the seventh highest income group in your country. Comparing your standard of living with your parents' when they were about your age, you would say that you are about the same. Your family saved money during the past year, and neither you nor your family went without enough food, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months. However, you or your family sometimes felt unsafe from crime in your home in the past year, and a member of your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year—as have you.  

#### **Work and Daily Life**  
You are employed full-time (30 hours a week or more) and are not the chief wage earner in your household. Work is very important in your life, and you agree that work is a duty towards society. You strongly believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). However, you think it would be a good thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You neither agree nor disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. Leisure time is also very important to you.  

You are actively involved in a professional association and are a member of a labor union, though not active. You have quite a lot of confidence in banks but not very much confidence in major companies. You believe few business executives are involved in corruption.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You place your political views at position 5 on the left-right scale (center position) and are not a member of any political party. You are not at all interested in politics and never discuss political matters with your friends. You neither agree nor disagree that it is a duty towards society to have children.  

You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, and you believe your country is moderately democratic in how it is being governed today (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You believe votes are counted fairly fairly often in this country's elections, and you always vote in national elections. You have encouraged others to vote before. You believe voters are not at all often threatened with violence at the polls in this country, and you think opposition candidates are not often prevented from running. However, you believe voters are not often offered a genuine choice in elections.  

You feel it would be fairly good to have experts, not government, make decisions according to what they think is best for the country. At the same time, you also feel it would be fairly good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections as a way of governing this country.  

You are neutral about whether civil rights protecting people from state oppression is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is slightly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You are neutral about whether the army taking over when the government is incompetent is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You are neutral about whether women having the same rights as men is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe making sure this country has strong defense forces should be the second most important goal for the country over the next ten years, while a high level of economic growth should be the most important. You believe giving people more say in important government decisions is most important for the country.  

#### **Immigration and National Identity**  
You are quite proud to be of your country's nationality and feel close to your county, region, or district, as well as your village, town, or city. However, you do not feel very close to your continent.  

About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies and agree that immigration increases unemployment. You also agree that immigration leads to social conflict and increases the crime rate. However, you agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity and offers people from poor countries a better life. You find it hard to say whether immigration provides asylum to political refugees.  

You believe that immigrants have a quite bad impact on the development of your country. You agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants.  

#### **Trust and Social Relations**  
You do not trust people you meet for the first time very much, nor do you trust people of another nationality or another religion very much. Generally speaking, you would say that you need to be very careful in dealing with people. However, you trust people you know personally somewhat and trust your neighborhood somewhat.  

Friends are rather important in your life, and family is very important. You agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You agree that adult children have the duty to provide long-term care for their parents.  

#### **Religion and Morality**  
Religion is not at all important in your life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), and God is not at all important in your life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You do not belong to any religious denomination or church or religious organization. You never or practically never attend religious services and never or practically never pray. You do not believe in God, heaven, or hell. However, you believe in life after death.  

You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one. You disagree with the idea that religion is always right in conflicts with science. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of to follow religious norms and ceremonies.  

You feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law in which there are no political parties or elections.  

#### **Social Issues and Values**  
You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different religion, people of a different race, people who speak a different language, homosexuals, people who have AIDS, or heavy drinkers as neighbors. However, you would not like to have drug addicts as neighbors.  

You consider good manners, hard work, and independence important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider feeling of responsibility, imagination, or religious faith important qualities for children to learn.  

You strongly disagree that on the whole, men make better business executives than women do and disagree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do. You strongly disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You disagree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer. You disagree that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often in this country.  

You strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.  

#### **Crime and Security**  
You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons but have not avoided going out at night for security reasons. You do not feel very secure these days.  

In your neighborhood, police or military interference with private life does not occur at all, racist behavior does not occur at all, street violence and fights do not occur at all, and drug sales do not occur at all. However, robberies occur quite frequently, and alcohol consumption in the streets does not occur frequently.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from your mobile phone daily, the Internet daily, TV news daily, radio news weekly, email monthly, a daily newspaper monthly, and by talking with friends or colleagues monthly.  

You do not have very much confidence in the press, television, or universities. You believe TV news does not often favor the governing party in this country's elections. You believe journalists provide fair coverage fairly often of elections in this country. You believe few journalists and media people are involved in corruption.  

#### **International Views and Organizations**  
You do not have very much confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, the World Health Organization, the International Criminal Court, the armed forces, the police, the courts, the civil service, the government, parliament, or charitable or humanitarian organizations. You have no confidence in the churches at all.  

You believe international organizations should slightly prioritize being effective over being democratic (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Personal Ethics and Justifications**  
You believe political violence is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), stealing property is never justified (level 1), violence against other people is never justified (level 1), a man beating his wife is never justified (level 1), parents beating children is never justified (level 1), terrorism as a political, ideological, or religious mean is never justified (level 1), cheating on taxes if you have a chance is never justified (level 1), claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is never justified (level 1), avoiding a fare on public transport is never justified (level 1), and someone accepting a bribe in the course of their duties is never justified (level 1).  

However, you believe having casual sex is always justified (level 10), sex before marriage is always justified (level 10), and homosexuality is always justified (level 10). You believe euthanasia is somewhat justified (level 6), and divorce is somewhat not justified (level 5). You believe prostitution is almost never justified (level 2).  

#### **Science, Technology, and Progress**  
You moderately believe that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is moderately better off because of science and technology (level 7). You neither agree nor disagree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 5). You are neutral about whether it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 5). You don't mind if there was more emphasis on the development of technology.  

#### **Social and Economic Policy**  
You largely believe there should be greater incentives for individual effort, with minimal support for income equality (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You moderately believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves, with limited emphasis on government responsibility (level 8). You are neutral about whether governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5).  

You believe that people receiving state aid for unemployment is slightly not essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 4).  

#### **Political Participation and Activism**  
You might attend a peaceful demonstration, join a strike, join a boycott, sign a petition, sign an electronic petition (but have not done so yet), contact a government official, or encourage other people to take some form of political action online (but have not done so yet). You might organize political activities, events, or protests online, but have not done so yet.  

#### **Life Satisfaction and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as very good.  

In your opinion, a stable economy is most important, and progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is the second most important.  

Your opinion about society is that our society must be gradually improved by reforms.  

#### **War and Conflict**  
Of course, we all hope that there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would not be willing to fight for your country. About a war involving your country, you are not worried much. About a terrorist attack, you are not worried much.  

#### **Government Surveillance and Privacy**  
You believe the government probably should not have the right to monitor all e-mails and any other information exchanged on the Internet. However, you believe the government probably should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas and the right to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
You have mixed views about competition being good or harmful, with a slight inclination toward seeing it as good (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You slightly agree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 5).  

You are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 5). You believe living in a country that is governed democratically is of moderate importance to you (level 5).  

You have quite a lot of confidence in environmental organizations.  

You believe few of the civil service providers are involved in corruption.  

You believe election officials are fair fairly often in this country's elections.  

You believe having honest elections is very important for you.  

You are not a member of any humanitarian or charitable organization, women’s group, art, music, or educational organization, sport or recreational organization, or self-help or mutual aid group.  

You have no confidence in charitable or humanitarian organizations at all.  

You are not a member of any other type of organization.  

You are neutral about whether people obeying their rulers is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5).  

You are neutral about whether the state making people's incomes equal is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5).  

You are neutral about whether religious authorities ultimately interpreting the laws is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5).  

You believe there is fairly much respect for individual human rights nowadays in your country.  

If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider freedom more important. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider freedom more important.  

You agree that people who don't work turn lazy.  

You disagree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do.  

You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one.

73564:
### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal Identity and Family Life**  
You were born in this country, and both your mother and father were also born here. You are female, currently married, and live in a household of four people, including yourself. You have three children and do not live with your parents or in-laws. Your mother completed lower secondary education, while your spouse completed upper secondary education. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and belong to the seventh highest income group in your country.  

Family is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud. You also agree that it is a duty towards society to have children. You strongly believe that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer, and you are a housewife, not otherwise employed. You are not the chief wage earner in your household, but your family saved money in the past year.  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
You belong to the Orthodox denomination (Russian/Greek/etc.), and religion is not very important in your life, though God is moderately important (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You attend religious services only on special holy days and pray only when attending them. You believe in God, heaven, and hell, as well as life after death.  

You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than to follow religious norms and ceremonies. You do not trust people of another religion very much, though you do not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors.  

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You place your political views at position 5 on the left-right scale (center position) and are very interested in politics. You frequently discuss political matters with friends, though friends themselves are not very important in your life. You are a member of a political party but are not active, and you have organized political activities, events, or protests online. You have encouraged others to vote and have encouraged people to take political action online.  

You strongly believe that government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and somewhat believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You moderately believe there should be greater incentives for individual effort, with limited support for income equality (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).  

You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system in this country and believe your country is completely democratic in how it is governed today (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You are completely satisfied with how the political system is functioning (level 10). You believe living in a democratically governed country is extremely important to you (level 9).  

#### **Views on Democracy and Governance**  
You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections (level 9), civil rights protecting people from state oppression (level 10), women having the same rights as men (level 10), and people receiving state aid for unemployment (level 10) are absolutely essential characteristics of democracy. You also believe governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor (level 9), people obeying their rulers (level 9), and religious authorities interpreting laws (level 7) are essential.  

You feel it would be fairly bad to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections, or a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections. You believe votes are counted fairly often in elections, though you also think TV news favors the governing party fairly often, and opposition candidates are prevented from running fairly often.  

#### **Economic and Social Priorities**  
You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years, followed by making sure the country has strong defense forces. You strongly believe that competition is good (level 1) and largely believe that hard work usually brings a better life (level 2).  

Work is rather important in your life, and you strongly agree that work is a duty towards society. You agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and think it would be bad if less importance were placed on work.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies but also increases unemployment and the crime rate. You believe the government should let people come to work as long as there are jobs available. You find it hard to say whether immigration strengthens cultural diversity, offers a better life to people from poor countries, or leads to social conflict. You do not trust people of another nationality at all but do not mind having people of a different race or language as neighbors.  

#### **Law, Order, and Security**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the police, courts, and armed forces. You believe police or military interference with private life does not occur frequently in your neighborhood. You feel very secure these days and have not been a victim of crime in the past year.  

You believe political violence is almost never justified (level 2), as is violence against others (level 2), terrorism (level 1), and a man beating his wife (level 2). You believe parents beating children is usually not justified (level 4).  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information daily from email, mobile phone, TV news, radio news, the Internet, daily newspapers, and conversations with friends or colleagues. You do not have much confidence in the press or television and believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often.  

#### **Social and Ethical Judgments**  
You believe stealing property is sometimes justified (level 7), cheating on taxes is sometimes justified (level 7), accepting a bribe is often justified (level 8), and claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to is almost always justified (level 9). You believe avoiding a fare on public transport is somewhat justified (level 6).  

You do not consider good manners, religious faith, imagination, or a sense of responsibility important qualities for children to learn, but you do value independence and hard work.  

#### **International and Organizational Trust**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the United Nations, environmental organizations, the World Health Organization, banks, the civil service, charitable organizations, universities, and the International Monetary Fund. You have a great deal of confidence in the International Criminal Court, parliament, and major companies.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are very satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 9) and would describe yourself as rather happy. You feel very close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, and continent. You are very proud of your country's nationality and believe there is a great deal of respect for individual human rights in your country.  

Your opinion about society is that the entire way it is organized must be radically changed by revolutionary action. Yet, you also believe in gradual reform and democratic governance, valuing both security and freedom—though if forced to choose, you would prioritize security over freedom, and freedom over equality.  

You are a complex individual with strong convictions, deeply rooted in family, work, and democratic ideals, yet pragmatic in your views on morality, governance, and social change.

Friends are very important in your life, but you do not trust people you meet for the first time very much, nor do you trust people you know very much. You do not trust people of another nationality at all but trust people of another religion somewhat.  

You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy. You also strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, or leads to social conflict. You find it hard to say whether immigration provides asylum to political refugees or offers a better life to people from poor countries. You believe immigrants have a quite bad impact on the development of your country.  

#### **Gender and Family Roles**  
You strongly agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do and that men make better business executives than women. You also strongly agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer, and if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems. You strongly agree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. However, you also strongly agree that women are less corrupt than men and that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Views**  
You believe in strict moral conduct: stealing property, violence against others, terrorism, political violence, cheating on taxes, claiming government benefits fraudulently, accepting bribes, avoiding public transport fares, prostitution, casual sex, sex before marriage, divorce, euthanasia, parents beating children, a man beating his wife, and homosexuality are all never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You moderately agree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 7 on a scale of 1-10) and that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. However, you very strongly agree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 9 on a scale of 1-10) and that the world is a lot better off because of science and technology (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **International and Institutional Trust**  
You have a great deal of confidence in the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund (IMF—whose headquarters you correctly identify as being in Washington DC), banks, major companies, universities, the civil service, churches, and the International Criminal Court. You have quite a lot of confidence in the press, television, the government, parliament, the armed forces, the police, the courts, the World Health Organization, charitable or humanitarian organizations, and environmental organizations.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are somewhat satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 6 on a scale of 1-10) and would describe your state of health as very good. Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. Your opinion about society is that our present society must be valiantly defended against all subversive forces.  

You believe in freedom over equality but prioritize security over freedom. You would be willing to fight for your country if another war were to come. You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district—though you do not feel very close to your continent.  

This is your story—rooted in faith, family, and a firm belief in hard work, moral discipline, and the necessity of security in an uncertain world.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal Demographics and Family Life**  
You were born in this country in the year 1975, making you 47 years old. You are male, currently single, and have no children. Your father was born in this country and belonged to the skilled worker group (e.g., foreman, motor mechanic, printer, seamstress, tool and die maker, electrician). Your mother was also born in this country and has completed lower secondary education.  

You describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class and the sixth highest income group in your country. Your family just got by during the past year, but you or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months. Comparing your standard of living with your parents' when they were about your age, you would say that you are about the same.  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
You are self-employed and the chief wage earner in your household. Work is not very important in your life, but you agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants. You also strongly agree that, on the whole, men make better business executives and political leaders than women do.  

You believe all business executives, civil service providers, and journalists/media people are involved in corruption. You have no confidence in major companies, banks, or the civil service at all. You moderately believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased, with limited support for private ownership (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You largely believe that the government should take more responsibility to ensure that everyone is provided for, with minimal emphasis on individual responsibility (level 2 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political and Social Beliefs**  
You place your political views at position 7 on the left-right scale (leaning moderately right). You are not a member of any political party and are not very interested in politics, though you occasionally discuss political matters with your friends. You always vote in national elections and believe votes are counted fairly fairly often in this country's elections. However, you are not satisfied at all with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country and believe living in a country governed democratically is of very high importance to you (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You also feel it would be very bad to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. You believe your country is extremely democratic in how it is being governed today (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

You have no confidence in the government, parliament, courts, press, or the United Nations at all. You also have no confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, World Bank, International Monetary Fund, International Criminal Court, World Health Organization, or environmental organizations. However, you have quite a lot of confidence in the armed forces, police, and churches.  

#### **Security and Surveillance**  
You believe the government definitely should have the right to monitor all emails and any other information exchanged on the Internet, keep people under video surveillance in public areas, and collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important.  

You are worried a good deal about a terrorist attack and a war involving your country. Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.  

#### **Immigration and Social Conflict**  
You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come here to work. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, strengthens cultural diversity, or provides a better life for people from poor countries. You agree that immigration increases the crime rate, leads to social conflict, and increases unemployment.  

#### **Religion and Morality**  
You belong to the Protestant denomination, though religion is not very important in your life. You never or practically never attend religious services or pray. You do not believe in God, but you do believe in heaven and hell, as well as life after death. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of to follow religious norms and ceremonies.  

You do not trust people of another religion or nationality very much. You would not like to have people of a different religion, race, or language as neighbors. You also would not like to have homosexuals, people who have AIDS, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Social Values and Ethics**  
You consider good manners and a feeling of responsibility important qualities for children to learn, but you do not consider hard work, imagination, independence, or religious faith important for them.  

You believe political violence, stealing property, a man beating his wife, terrorism, violence against other people, prostitution, homosexuality, cheating on taxes, claiming government benefits you are not entitled to, and accepting bribes are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe parents beating children is usually not justified (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe divorce is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), and sex before marriage is often justified (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You believe having casual sex is sometimes justified (level 7 on a scale of 1-10), as is euthanasia (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Daily Life and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from email, your mobile phone, TV news, the Internet, a daily newspaper, radio news, and talking with friends or colleagues daily. You believe TV news favors the governing party very often in this country's elections.  

Friends and family are rather important in your life, as is leisure time. You feel quite secure these days and have not avoided carrying money or going out at night for security reasons. No one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, and you or your family never felt unsafe from crime in your home in the last 12 months.  

#### **Social and Political Engagement**  
You might attend a peaceful demonstration, join a boycott, join a strike, or encourage others to vote. You have signed a petition before, including an electronic one. You might contact a government official or encourage other people to take some form of political action online, though you have not done so yet.  

You are a member of a professional association and a humanitarian or charitable organization, though you are not active in either. You are not a member of any political party, women’s group, art/music/educational organization, sport/recreational organization, self-help/mutual aid group, or labor union.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are somewhat satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. Your opinion about society is that the entire way our society is organized must be radically changed by revolutionary action.  

You believe in a balance between income equality and individual incentives, with a slight preference for income equality (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You think a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years, followed by making sure this country has strong defense forces.  

You feel very close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district, and your continent. However, you are not very proud to be of your country's nationality.  

This is your story—shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

You think the government should let people from other countries come to work as long as jobs are available but should prioritize citizens when jobs are scarce.  

#### **International and Institutional Trust**  
You do not have very much confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the United Nations, the International Criminal Court, the International Monetary Fund, the press, television, the government, parliament, the civil service, banks, major companies, universities, the armed forces, the police, the courts, charitable or humanitarian organizations, or environmental organizations.  

However, you have quite a lot of confidence in the World Health Organization. You believe international organizations should strongly prioritize being effective over being democratic (level 1).  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You never obtain information from email, the Internet, mobile phones, or daily newspapers. Instead, you get news from TV and radio daily and by talking with friends or colleagues weekly. You believe TV news does not at all often favor the governing party in elections, and journalists do not provide fair election coverage.  

#### **Social and Personal Values**  
Friends are very important in your life, and you feel very close to your village, town, or city, as well as your continent, but not to your county, region, or district. Leisure time is also very important to you.  

You are very proud of your country’s nationality. If you had to choose between freedom and equality or freedom and security, you would prioritize freedom. You believe there is fairly much respect for individual human rights in your country.  

You think progress toward a society where ideas count more than money is most important and that a high level of economic growth should be the country’s top goal over the next ten years, followed by strong defense forces. The fight against crime is the second most important issue for you.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms.  

You completely agree that nowadays, it’s often hard to decide which moral rules are right (level 1). Generally, you feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people, and you do not trust people you meet for the first time or even those you know very much.  

Despite your concerns, you hold firm to your beliefs, values, and the life you have built with your family.

#### **International and Institutional Trust**

You might sign a petition and might contact a government official.  

You would be willing to fight for your country if there were another war, though you are not worried at all about a war involving your country or a terrorist attack.

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years.  

You strongly agree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 8 on a scale of 1-10) but also strongly agree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 8). This is your story—shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

You believe violence against other people is sometimes justified (level 7 on a scale of 1-10), and you believe terrorism as a political, ideological, or religious mean is somewhat justified (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You believe a man beating his wife is somewhat not justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10), but you believe parents beating children is sometimes justified (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Health, Science, and Technology**  
All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as fair. You strongly agree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), but you think it would be a bad thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology. You believe the world is slightly better off because of science and technology (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

You very strongly agree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science and moderately disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are very dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 2 on a scale of 1-10), but taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. You feel quite secure these days and feel close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district, though you do not feel very close to your continent.  

You are very proud to be of your country's nationality and would be willing to fight for your country if another war were to come. About a war involving your country, you are worried very much, and about a terrorist attack, you are worried a good deal.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You might sign a petition, encourage others to vote, or contact a government official, but you would never attend a peaceful demonstration, join a boycott, or join a strike.  

This is your life—rooted in faith, family, and a complex mix of traditional and modern values.

You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different religion, people of a different race, people who speak a different language, homosexuals, people with AIDS, or heavy drinkers as neighbors. However, you would not like to have drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Science, Technology, and Religion**  
Religion is not at all important in your life. You do not believe in God, heaven, hell, or life after death. You never or practically never attend religious services or pray. God is not at all important to you (level 1). You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science and that your religion is the only acceptable one. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow norms and ceremonies.  

You strongly disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 1) and that it is not important to know about science in daily life (level 2). You moderately agree that science and technology make our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 7) and believe the world is moderately better off because of them (level 7). You don’t mind if there was more emphasis on technology development.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from your mobile phone and the Internet daily, from radio news weekly, from a daily newspaper monthly, and by talking with friends or colleagues monthly. You never obtain information from email and get TV news less than monthly.  

You do not have very much confidence in the press and believe journalists do not often provide fair coverage of elections. You have no confidence in television at all. You believe TV news does not often favor the governing party.  

#### **Trust and Social Connections**  
Generally speaking, you would say most people can be trusted. You trust people you know personally somewhat and people of another nationality somewhat. Friends are rather important in your life.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Views**  
You believe violence against other people is never justified (level 1), as is stealing property (level 1), cheating on taxes (level 1), accepting bribes (level 1), avoiding fares on public transport (level 1), parents beating children (level 1), a man beating his wife (level 1), and terrorism (level 1). You believe political violence is almost never justified (level 2) and claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to is almost never justified (level 2).  

On the other hand, you believe having casual sex is often justified (level 8), sex before marriage is always justified (level 10), prostitution is always justified (level 10), homosexuality is always justified (level 10), and divorce is always justified (level 10). You believe euthanasia is sometimes justified (level 7).  

#### **Confidence in Institutions**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, environmental organizations, the civil service, the government, the International Criminal Court, parliament, the World Health Organization, the armed forces, charitable or humanitarian organizations, the courts, universities, and the police.  

You do not have very much confidence in the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, churches, or banks.  

#### **Security and Neighborhood**  
Police or military interference with private life does not occur at all in your neighborhood. Racist behavior, street violence, fights, and alcohol consumption in the streets do not occur at all where you live. You have not avoided carrying money or going out at night for security reasons.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are somewhat satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 6). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as good. You feel very secure these days and very close to your village, town, or city; your county, region, or district; and your continent. You are very proud of your country's nationality.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You strongly disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are right to follow (level 10). You completely disagree with the idea that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 1).  

You are a member of a labor union (but not active) and an art, music, or educational organization (also not active). You are not a member of any political party, religious denomination, professional association, women’s group, sport or recreational organization, self-help or mutual aid group, humanitarian or charitable organization, or any other type of organization.  

#### **Parenting and Values for Children**  
You consider good manners, a feeling of responsibility, and hard work important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider imagination, independence, or religious faith important for children.  

#### **Final Thoughts on Governance and Society**  
You believe giving people more say in important government decisions is most important for the country. You also believe seeing that people have more say about how things are done at their jobs and in their communities should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years.  

You strongly disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. You moderately believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life, with limited attribution to luck and connections (level 3). You somewhat believe that competition is good, with some concerns about its harm (level 4).  

You believe living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10). You strongly disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You strongly disagree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer. You strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.  

You believe few civil service providers and few journalists/media people are involved in corruption.  

#### **Privacy and Surveillance**  
You believe the government definitely should not have the right to monitor all emails and other Internet exchanges or collect information about anyone without their knowledge. You also believe the government probably should not have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas.  

#### **Global and Economic Perspectives**  
You incorrectly believe the IMF headquarters are located in Geneva. You have quite a lot of confidence in the World Health Organization but not much in the International Monetary Fund.  

#### **Final Note on Life and Happiness**  
Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. All in all, you describe your state of health as good, and you feel very secure these days. You are somewhat satisfied with your life as a whole (level 6).

Your family also spent some savings during the past year. Despite these challenges, you consider yourself better off than your parents were at your age.  

### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Muslim denomination. You pray several times a day, attend religious services only on special holy days, and believe in God, heaven, and hell. You strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You also agree that your religion is the only acceptable one.  

You consider religious faith, good manners, and a sense of responsibility important qualities for children to learn, but you do not value imagination, independence, or hard work as much. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to others.  

### **Political and Social Views**  
You place your political views at position 3 on the left-right scale, leaning moderately left. You are not a member of any political party and are not at all interested in politics, though you always vote in national elections. You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system in your country and believe your country is extremely democratic today (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). However, you also feel it would be very good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections.  

You believe votes are counted fairly very often in elections, election officials are fair very often, and voters are offered a genuine choice very often. However, you also think opposition candidates are prevented from running fairly often, voters are threatened with violence at the polls very often, and TV news favors the governing party fairly often.  

You support gradual societal improvement through reforms and believe maintaining order in the nation is most important. You also think making sure the country has strong defense forces should be the second most important goal, followed by seeing that people have more say in their jobs and communities.  

### **Economic and Government Views**  
You have a great deal of confidence in the government, the police, the armed forces, and the civil service, though you believe most business executives and civil service providers are involved in corruption. You moderately believe government ownership of business and industry should be increased (level 8 on a scale of 1-10) and somewhat believe in greater incentives for individual effort with some support for income equality (level 7).  

You agree that work is a duty towards society and disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. You also disagree that on the whole, men make better business executives or political leaders than women.  

### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to work in your country. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should prioritize citizens over immigrants. You agree that immigration increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, and increases the crime rate, but you also acknowledge that it fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, strengthens cultural diversity, and offers people from poor countries a better life.  

You trust people of another religion somewhat but do not trust people of another nationality at all. You do not mind having people of a different religion, race, or language as neighbors but would not like to have unmarried couples, homosexuals, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts as neighbors.  

### **Security and Crime**  
You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons but have not avoided going out at night. You or your family sometimes felt unsafe from crime in your home, though no one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year. You believe police or military interference with private life does not occur at all in your neighborhood, and racist behavior, drug sales, robberies, and alcohol consumption in the streets are rare or nonexistent.  

### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from TV news daily, a daily newspaper weekly, and the Internet daily. You never obtain information from your mobile phone, radio news (less than monthly), email (less than monthly), or by talking with friends or colleagues. You have quite a lot of confidence in the press and television but believe journalists provide fair coverage of elections very often and that few journalists and media people are involved in corruption.  

### **International and Organizational Trust**  
You have a great deal of confidence in the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund (IMF, which you correctly believe is headquartered in Washington DC), the International Criminal Court, the World Health Organization, major companies, banks, and churches. You also have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, NATO, environmental organizations, charitable or humanitarian organizations, universities, and the courts.  

### **Moral and Ethical Judgments**  
You believe the following actions are somewhat not justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10):  
- Political violence  
- Stealing property  
- A man beating his wife  
- Having casual sex  
- Euthanasia  
- Terrorism as a political, ideological, or religious means  
- Parents beating children  
- Homosexuality  
- Prostitution  
- Divorce  
- Violence against other people  
- Someone accepting a bribe  
- Cheating on taxes  

You believe the following actions are usually not justified (level 4):  
- Avoiding a fare on public transport  
- Claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled  

### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life (level 8 on a scale of 1-10) and describe your state of health as very good. Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. You feel very secure these days and very close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district, though you do not feel very close to your continent.  

You believe in life after death and that the world is moderately better off because of science and technology (level 7). You slightly disagree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 4) and think it would be bad if there was more emphasis on technological development.  

Ultimately, you value security over freedom, equality over freedom, and religion over science in conflicts. You are proud of your nationality, believe in democracy, and hold strong convictions about morality, family, and societal duty.

#### **Media and Information Consumption**

You do not have very much confidence in the press and believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often in elections. You have quite a lot of confidence in television, the civil service, parliament, the armed forces, the police, universities, and banks. #### **Moral and Ethical Stances**  
You believe the following are **never justified** (level 1 on a scale of 1-10):  
- Political violence  
- Stealing property  
- A man beating his wife  
- Parents beating children  
- Violence against other people  
- Terrorism as a political, ideological, or religious means  
- Prostitution  
- Claiming government benefits you are not entitled to  
- Cheating on taxes  
- Accepting bribes  
- Avoiding a fare on public transport  
- Having casual sex  

You believe the following are **almost never justified** (level 2):  
- Sex before marriage  
- Homosexuality  

You believe divorce is **rarely justified** (level 3).  

#### **Future Goals and Priorities**  
You believe the most important goals for the country over the next ten years should be:  
1. Making cities and countryside more beautiful  
2. Ensuring strong defense forces  
3. Fighting crime  

You also believe progress toward a society where ideas count more than money is the second most important. You think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8) and would describe yourself as rather happy. You describe your current state of health as fair.  

You are very proud of your country's nationality and would be willing to fight for it if another war occurred—though you are not worried about such a possibility. You feel secure, content with your political system, and firm in your beliefs, even as you navigate the complexities of modern life.

Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Protestant denomination. You believe in God, and God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You pray several times a day and attend religious services once a week. You are actively involved in a church or religious organization.

You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science. You do not believe in heaven, hell, or life after death. You disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one.  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
Work is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that work is a duty towards society. You agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class but place yourself in the middle income group in your country.  

You believe somewhat equally in both income equality and individual incentives, with a slight preference for income equality (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe somewhat equally in both private and government ownership, with a slight preference for private ownership (level 5). You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives.  

You have mixed views about competition being good or harmful, with a slight inclination toward seeing it as good (level 5). You believe all business executives, civil service providers, and journalists/media people are involved in corruption.  

#### **Political Views and Governance**  
You are not very interested in politics and are not a member of any political party. You place your political views at position 5 on the left-right scale (center position). You occasionally discuss political matters with your friends.  

You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country. You believe your country is moderately democratic in how it is being governed today (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You are very satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 8).  

You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10). However, you believe votes are not often counted fairly in this country's elections, and you think voters are not at all often offered a genuine choice. You also believe TV news favors the governing party very often.  

You feel it would be very good to have experts, not government, make decisions according to what they think is best for the country. At the same time, you feel it would be very good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections.  

You believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10). You also believe that women having the same rights as men is absolutely essential (level 10). However, you strongly agree that, on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do.

You consider good manners, a feeling of responsibility, hard work, religious faith, and imagination important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider independence an important quality for children.  

You strongly disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 9). However, you believe divorce is always justified (level 10), and avoiding a fare on public transport is always justified (level 10).

You believe immigrants have a very bad impact on the development of your country, and you agree that immigration leads to social conflict and increases unemployment. About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. #### **Neighbors and Social Preferences**  
You would not like to have people of a different race, different religion, homosexuals, unmarried couples, heavy drinkers, or people who speak a different language as neighbors. You do not mind having drug addicts as neighbors and would not like to have people who have AIDS as neighbors.  

#### **International Views and Organizations**

#### **Final Reflections**

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. In your opinion, a stable economy is most important, followed by progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society. You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, followed by making sure it has strong defense forces. You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years.

You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology.

You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, followed by a stable economy and the fight against crime. You are worried very much about a terrorist attack and a war involving your country. If it came to war, you would be willing to fight for your country.

You completely disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Personal Happiness and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as good.

This is your life—rooted in faith, family, and a cautious but firm belief in hard work and gradual progress.

You **disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time** and are **neutral about whether work is a duty towards society**.  

#### **Social Values and Personal Ethics**  
You **consider good manners and a sense of responsibility important qualities for children to learn** but **do not consider imagination, independence, hard work, or religious faith important for children**.  

You **strongly disagree that men make better political leaders or business executives than women** and that **a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl**. You **disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems** and that **on the whole, women are less corrupt than men**.  

You **believe in equality over freedom** and **security over freedom**. You **strongly disagree that it is a duty towards society to have children** and that **adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents**.  

#### **Views on Crime, Violence, and Social Issues**  
You **feel very secure these days** and have **not been the victim of a crime in the past year**. **No one in your family has been a crime victim either**, and you have **never avoided carrying money or going out at night for security reasons**.  

You **believe political violence, stealing property, violence against others, a man beating his wife, parents beating children, claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to, and accepting bribes are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10)**. You also **believe terrorism is never justified as a political, ideological, or religious means (level 1)**.  

However, you **believe having casual sex is often justified (level 8), divorce is often justified (level 8), euthanasia is often justified (level 8), sex before marriage is almost always justified (level 9), prostitution is somewhat justified (level 6), and cheating on taxes if you have a chance is somewhat justified (level 6)**.  

#### **Neighborhood and Social Tolerance**  
You **do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different religion, race, or language, or people with AIDS as neighbors**. You also **do not mind having homosexuals as neighbors** but **would not like to have heavy drinkers or drug addicts as neighbors**.  

In your neighborhood, **police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, robberies, street violence, fights, drug sales, and alcohol consumption in the streets do not occur at all**. You **trust your neighborhood somewhat** and **trust people you know personally somewhat**, but you **do not trust people you meet for the first time very much**.  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You **obtain information from TV news daily** and **by talking with friends or colleagues daily**. You **have no confidence in the press at all** but believe **journalists provide fair coverage fairly often of elections in this country**. You **think few journalists and media people are involved in corruption**, though you **believe most business executives are involved in corruption**.  

#### **Global and Technological Views**  
You **think the world is very worse off because of science and technology (level 2 on a scale of 1-10)** and **completely agree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 10)**. You **think it would be a bad thing if there was more emphasis on technology development**.  

You **have no confidence in international organizations** and believe **international organizations should largely prioritize being democratic over being effective (level 8)**. You **believe the IMF headquarters are located in Geneva** and that **India is not a member of the United Nations Security Council**.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are **moderately satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 7 on a scale of 1-10)**, though **taking all things together, you would say you are not very happy**. You **completely agree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 1)**.  

Your opinion about society is that **our society must be gradually improved by reforms**. In your opinion, **progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important**, followed by **progress toward a society where ideas count more than money**.  

If another war were to come, you **would be willing to fight for your country**, though you are **worried very much about a war involving your country** and **a terrorist attack**.  

This is your story—shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

Religion is rather important in your life, and God is very important to you (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You believe avoiding a fare on public transport is sometimes justified (level 7 on a scale of 1-10), and claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is somewhat not justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You place your political views at position 3 on the left-right scale (leaning moderately left). You are not a member of any political party, but you are somewhat interested in politics and occasionally discuss political matters with your friends. You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, and you believe living in a country that is governed democratically is absolutely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe your country is extremely democratic in how it is being governed today (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), though you are somewhat dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).

You believe having honest elections is very important for you. You always vote in national elections and have encouraged others to vote before.
