#### **Social and Economic Views**  
You feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law in which there are no political parties or elections. You feel it would be fairly good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections and very good to have experts, not government, make decisions according to what they think is best for the country.  

You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, followed by making sure this country has strong defense forces and trying to make our cities and countryside more beautiful. In your opinion, progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important, followed by progress toward a society in which ideas count more than money.  

You somewhat believe that incomes should be made more equal, with some support for individual incentives (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that the state making people's incomes equal is slightly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), but governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is not essential (level 1). You believe that women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10).  

You agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women and that employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants. You strongly agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer and that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems. However, you disagree that on the whole, men make better political leaders or business executives than women do.  

#### **Work and Daily Life**  
Work is very important in your life, and you are employed full-time (30 hours a week or more). You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You agree that work is a duty towards society but disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. Leisure time is not at all important in your life.  

You believe both hard work and luck/connections play important roles in success, with a slight emphasis on hard work (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You disagree that people who don’t work turn lazy.  

#### **Immigration and National Identity**  
You are very proud to be of your country's nationality and feel very close to your village, town, or city; your county, region, or district; and your continent. If it came to war, you would be willing to fight for your country.  

About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come. You believe that immigrants have a quite bad impact on the development of your country. You find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, strengthens cultural diversity, increases the crime rate, leads to social conflict, increases unemployment, or offers a better life to people from poor countries.  

#### **Trust and Social Relations**  
You do not trust people of another religion or nationality at all. You do not trust people you meet for the first time at all, but you trust people you know personally somewhat and your neighborhood somewhat. Generally speaking, you would say that you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

Friends are not very important in your life. You do not mind having people of a different religion, race, or language as neighbors, or having unmarried couples or homosexuals as neighbors. However, you would not like to have people who have AIDS, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Security and Safety**  
You have avoided carrying much money and going out at night for security reasons. Robberies occur quite frequently in your neighborhood, but street violence and fights, alcohol consumption, and drug sales do not occur at all. Police or military interference with private life does not occur at all in your neighborhood.  

You or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months. You or your family never felt unsafe from crime in your home, and no one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year. You have not been a victim of crime in the past year either.  

About a terrorist attack or a war involving your country, you are worried very much. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from TV news daily, your mobile phone daily, the Internet monthly, a daily newspaper less than monthly, radio news less than monthly, and by talking with friends or colleagues less than monthly. You never obtain information from email.  

You have no confidence in the press at all and believe most journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You believe TV news does not often favor the governing party in this country's elections, and journalists do not often provide fair coverage of elections. You do not have very much confidence in television.  

#### **Institutional Trust and Corruption**  
You have a great deal of confidence in the World Bank, the United Nations, and universities. You have quite a lot of confidence in banks, major companies, the World Health Organization, the armed forces, the police, and the International Monetary Fund. You have no confidence in parliament at all and do not have very much confidence in the government, courts, churches, charitable or humanitarian organizations, the International Criminal Court, or environmental organizations.  

You believe most business executives and civil service providers are involved in corruption. You agree that on the whole, women are less corrupt than men.  

#### **Science and Technology**  
You slightly disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You moderately agree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is moderately better off because of science and technology (level 7). You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology.  

You disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as good. You feel quite secure these days.  

Your opinion about society is that our society must be gradually improved by reforms. You are actively involved in a women’s group and a self-help or mutual aid group. You are a member of a labor union and a sport or recreational organization, though not active in either. You are not a member of any political party, professional association, art/music/educational organization, humanitarian/charitable organization, or other type of organization.  

You believe the IMF headquarters are located in London and that France is not a member of the United Nations Security Council.  

### **Conclusion**  
You are a 24-year-old woman with strong moral convictions, a deep sense of national pride, and a cautious but engaged approach to politics and society. While you value democracy and individual rights, you prioritize security and order. Family and work are central to your life, and though you are skeptical of many institutions, you maintain faith in some international organizations. Your views on immigration, gender roles, and religion reflect a complex blend of traditional and modern perspectives. Despite challenges, you find fulfillment in your life and remain hopeful for gradual societal improvement.

You strongly oppose many behaviors, believing they are never justified: stealing property (level 1), violence against others (level 1), political violence (level 1), a man beating his wife (level 1), parents beating children (level 1), casual sex (level 1), sex before marriage (level 1), prostitution (level 1), homosexuality (level 1), divorce (level 1), euthanasia (level 1), terrorism (level 1), cheating on taxes (level 1), accepting bribes (level 1), and avoiding fares on public transport (level 1).  

You consider good manners and a sense of responsibility important qualities for children to learn but do not value imagination, independence, religious faith, or hard work as much.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are somewhat interested in politics and occasionally discuss political matters with friends, though you are not a member of any political party. You believe your country is somewhat democratic (level 6) but feel votes are not often counted fairly, election officials are not often fair, and voters are not offered a genuine choice. You have quite a lot of confidence in the government but not much in parliament, the police, or the courts.  

You strongly believe government ownership of business and industry should be increased (level 10) and that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves (level 10). You also strongly believe in greater incentives for individual effort (level 10) and that hard work usually brings a better life (level 1, though this seems contradictory).  

You prioritize security over freedom and believe the government should have the right to monitor all emails, collect information about anyone without their knowledge, and keep people under video surveillance in public areas. You feel maintaining order in the nation is most important, followed by ensuring strong defense forces.  

You oppose democracy as a governing system, religious law governance, and rule by experts instead of government. You also dislike the idea of a strong leader bypassing parliament and elections. You believe opposition candidates are not often prevented from running, voters are not threatened with violence, and journalists do not provide fair election coverage.  

#### **Economic and Work Perspectives**  
Work is not very important in your life, but you agree that work is a duty towards society and should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You believe people who don’t work turn lazy and that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. You also think men make better business executives and political leaders than women, though you agree women are less corrupt.  

You strongly disagree that children suffer when a mother works for pay. You believe most business executives, civil service providers, and journalists are involved in corruption.  

#### **Immigration and National Identity**  
You are quite proud of your country's nationality and feel close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district—though not your continent. You would be willing to fight for your country if war broke out.  

You have mixed views on immigration. You believe the government should let people come to work as long as jobs are available, and you agree immigration strengthens cultural diversity and offers people from poor countries a better life. However, you also think immigration increases unemployment, social conflict, and crime. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies or provides asylum to political refugees.

You obtain information daily from TV news, your mobile phone, and conversations with friends or colleagues. You have quite a lot of confidence in television, the press, and banks but not much in the civil service.

Friends are very important in your life, though you generally need to be very careful in dealing with people. You trust your neighborhood somewhat, as well as people of another religion or nationality, but not those you meet for the first time.

This is your story—shaped by your beliefs, experiences, and the world around you.

You feel quite secure these days and have not been the victim of a crime in the past year. No one in your family has been a victim of crime either. You have avoided going out at night for security reasons but have not avoided carrying money for the same reason.  

In your neighborhood, police or military interference with private life does not occur at all, nor do robberies, racist behavior, street violence, fights, or alcohol consumption in the streets. Drug sales do not occur frequently in your area. You trust your neighborhood somewhat.  

You believe the government definitely should not have the right to monitor all emails and online exchanges, and it probably should not have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas or collect information about anyone without their knowledge.  

#### **Religion and Morality**  
Religion is not at all important in your life, and you never or practically never attend religious services or pray. You do not believe in God, heaven, or hell, and you strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to others.  

You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science. You believe in life after death but do not belong to any religious denomination or church.  

#### **Social and Ethical Values**  
You believe in equality over freedom if forced to choose, and security over freedom if given that choice. You consider responsibility and imagination important qualities for children to learn but do not value good manners, independence, hard work, or religious faith as much.  

You strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples and do not mind having homosexuals, unmarried couples, people of a different race, religion, or language, or people with AIDS as neighbors. However, you would not like to have heavy drinkers or drug addicts as neighbors.  

You believe political violence is rarely justified (level 3), violence against others is almost never justified (level 2), and terrorism is almost never justified (level 2). You also believe stealing property is almost never justified (level 2), cheating on taxes is rarely justified (level 3), and claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to is somewhat not justified (level 5).  

You believe having casual sex, sex before marriage, divorce, and homosexuality are always justified (level 10 for each), while prostitution is usually not justified (level 4), and euthanasia is somewhat justified (level 6).  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You never obtain information from email or daily newspapers but get news from TV monthly, radio weekly, the Internet weekly, and conversations with friends or colleagues weekly. You obtain information from your mobile phone less than monthly.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the press, television, and universities, and you believe TV news does not often favor the governing party in elections. You also believe journalists provide fair election coverage fairly often.  

#### **Health and Well-being**  
All in all, you describe your state of health as good. Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy, though you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
You are very proud of your country’s nationality and feel close to your continent and county, region, or district—though not to your village, town, or city. You believe progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important, followed by a stable economy and high economic growth.  

You strongly agree that science and technology make life healthier, easier, and more comfortable, and you believe the world is much better off because of them (level 8). You slightly disagree that knowing about science is unimportant in daily life (level 4) and moderately disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 3).  

Ultimately, your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms, and you believe in living in a country governed democratically—something that is absolutely important to you (level 10).

In your opinion, **progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important**, followed by **progress toward a society in which ideas count more than money**.

You believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often in this country's elections, and you believe journalists provide fair coverage fairly often of elections.  

#### **International and Organizational Trust**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the United Nations, environmental organizations, the International Criminal Court, major companies, charitable or humanitarian organizations, the International Monetary Fund, universities, and the World Health Organization. #### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You believe political violence, stealing property, violence against other people, having casual sex, avoiding a fare on public transport, terrorism as a political/ideological/religious means, prostitution, homosexuality, and sex before marriage are almost never justified (level 2 on a scale of 1-10).

You believe divorce is somewhat not justified (level 5), and claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is somewhat justified (level 6). You believe cheating on taxes if you have a chance is somewhat not justified (level 5), and someone accepting a bribe in the course of their duties is rarely justified (level 3).  

#### **Future Aspirations and Concerns**  
You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years, followed by seeing that people have more say about how things are done at their jobs and in their communities. Maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country.  

You are worried very much about a terrorist attack and a good deal about a war involving your country. If it came to war, you would be willing to fight for your country. If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider equality more important. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are very satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. You feel quite secure these days. Your opinion about society is that the entire way our society is organized must be radically changed by revolutionary action.  

You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district, though you do not feel very close to your continent. In your opinion, a stable economy is most important.  

You are a member of a labor union, a church or religious organization, and a humanitarian or charitable organization, though you are not active in any of them. You are not a member of any political party, professional association, sport or recreational organization, self-help or mutual aid group, or any other type of organization.  

You are actively involved in an art, music, or educational organization. Leisure time is very important in your life, though you think it would be a bad thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology.  

You believe the government probably should not have the right to monitor all emails and other Internet exchanges or collect information about anyone without their knowledge, but it probably should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas.  

You believe the world is neither better nor worse off because of science and technology (level 5 on a scale of 1-10), though you very strongly agree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 9). You slightly disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 6).  

This is your life—shaped by faith, family, work, and a deep belief in democracy, even as you hold strong reservations about those who differ from you. You navigate the world with caution, pride, and a firm sense of what you believe is right.

#### **Final Thoughts**  
You are **quite proud of your country's nationality** and feel **close to your village, town, or city, your county, region, or district, and your continent**. If another war were to come, you **would be willing to fight for your country**.  

You **strongly disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems**, that **men make better business executives or political leaders than women**, and that **a university education is more important for a boy than a girl**. You **believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often** and that **homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples**.  

You **consider good manners, independence, and hard work important qualities for children to learn** but **do not consider imagination, religious faith, or a feeling of responsibility important**.  

You are **actively involved in a humanitarian or charitable organization and another type of organization** but **do not have very much confidence in charitable or humanitarian organizations**.  

You **obtain information from TV news and radio news daily, the Internet daily, email weekly, and by talking with friends or colleagues weekly**, but you **never obtain information from a daily newspaper**.  

You **believe India is not a member of the United Nations Security Council** and that the **IMF headquarters are located in Washington DC**.  

Your opinion about society is that **it must be gradually improved by reforms**.  

**All in all, you are a man of strong convictions, balancing tradition with progressive values, deeply engaged in civic life, and committed to democracy, family, and personal integrity.**

#### **Views on Democracy and Governance**

You believe most business executives, civil service providers, and journalists are involved in corruption. You moderately agree that competition is good, with limited concerns about its harm (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). ### **Political and Social Beliefs**  
You place your political views at position 9 on the left-right scale (very strongly right). You are somewhat interested in politics but are not a member of any political party. You feel it would be fairly bad to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country and would prefer a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. You believe your country is moderately democratic today (level 5 on a scale of 1-10) and that maintaining order in the nation is most important.  

You strongly believe that making sure the country has strong defense forces should be the most important goal over the next ten years, followed by a high level of economic growth. You are neutral about many aspects of democracy, including whether people choose leaders in free elections, whether women have the same rights as men, and whether governments tax the rich to subsidize the poor (all level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe political violence, terrorism, and violence against others are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You are worried very much about a terrorist attack and a good deal about a war involving your country. If it came to war, you would be willing to fight for your country.  

### **Religion and Morality**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Roman Catholic denomination. God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and you believe in heaven and hell, but not in life after death. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to others. You attend religious services and pray less often than once a year but are actively involved in a church or religious organization.  

You consider good manners, a sense of responsibility, and hard work important qualities for children to learn, but not imagination, independence, or religious faith. You believe stealing, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, fare-dodging, and prostitution are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe divorce is somewhat justified (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), while sex before marriage is somewhat not justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

### **Immigration and Social Issues**  
You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies and provides asylum to political refugees, but also that it increases unemployment, social conflict, and crime. You believe the government should let people come to work as long as jobs are available but should prioritize citizens when jobs are scarce. You find it hard to say whether immigration strengthens cultural diversity or offers a better life to people from poor countries.  

You do not mind having people of a different religion, race, or those with AIDS as neighbors, but you would not like heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people who speak a different language as neighbors. You do not mind unmarried couples or homosexuals living nearby.  

### **Trust and Confidence in Institutions**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the armed forces, the police, the civil service, the United Nations, NATO, the World Bank, and churches. You have less confidence in the press, television, banks, major companies, universities, environmental organizations, the International Monetary Fund, the International Criminal Court, and the World Health Organization.  

You trust people you know personally, your neighborhood, and people of another religion or nationality somewhat, but generally, you feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

### **Media and Information Habits**  
You obtain information from TV news, email, the Internet, and your mobile phone daily, and from radio news daily as well. You also get information from a daily newspaper weekly and by talking with friends or colleagues weekly.  

### **Security and Neighborhood**  
You have not avoided carrying money or going out at night for security reasons. No one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year, and you or your family never felt unsafe from crime at home. Police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, robberies, drug sales, street violence, and alcohol consumption in the streets do not occur frequently in your neighborhood.  

### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life (level 8 on a scale of 1-10) and describe yourself as rather happy. You believe our society must be gradually improved by reforms. You feel very close to your village, town, or city, and your county, region, or district, but not to your continent. You are very proud of your country's nationality.  

This is your story—shaped by your beliefs, experiences, and the world around you.

### **Your Comprehensive Backstory**  

#### **Personal Background and Family Life**  
You were born in this country in the year 1958, making you 60 years old. You are male, currently married, and live regularly in a household of four people, including yourself. You have two children and do not live with your parents or in-laws. Your spouse has never had a job and has completed primary education. Neither your father nor your mother had formal jobs, and your mother has no formal education or only early childhood education. Both your father and mother were born in country 50, though your mother was also born in this country.  

Family is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud. You also strongly agree that it is a duty towards society to have children. You and your family have never gone without enough food, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months, and you have not felt unsafe from crime in your home during that time.  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Muslim denomination. You believe in God, heaven, and hell, and you pray several times a day. You attend religious services more than once a week. God is very important to you (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to other people.  

You agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you do not trust people of another religion at all. However, you do not mind having people of a different religion or those who speak a different language as neighbors. You strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are not at all interested in politics and are not a member of any political party. You place your political views at position 3 on the left-right scale, leaning moderately left. You never discuss political matters with your friends. You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, but you also feel it would be very good to have a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections.  

You believe living in a democratically governed country is of high importance to you (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel very close to your village, town, city, county, region, and continent. You would be willing to fight for your country if another war were to come.  

You believe votes are not at all often counted fairly in this country's elections, voters are not often offered a genuine choice, and election officials are not often fair. You also believe opposition candidates are not often prevented from running, and journalists do not often provide fair coverage of elections. Despite this, you usually vote in national elections, though you would never encourage others to vote.  

#### **Economic and Work Ethic**  
You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and the middle-income group in your country. Work is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You agree that work is a duty towards society. You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives.  

You moderately believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves, with limited emphasis on government responsibility (level 8). You somewhat believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life, though you acknowledge some role for luck and connections (level 4). You believe few business executives are involved in corruption, though you think most civil service providers, journalists, and media people are.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies or provides asylum to political refugees. You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to work here. You agree that immigration increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, and increases the crime rate. However, you also believe immigrants have a quite good impact on the development of your country and agree that immigration offers people from poor countries a better life.  

You do not trust people of another nationality at all and would not like to have people of a different race as neighbors. You also would not like to have unmarried couples, homosexuals, people who have AIDS, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Security and Surveillance**  
You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons but have not avoided going out at night. You are worried a good deal about a terrorist attack and very much about a war involving your country. You believe the government probably should have the right to monitor all emails and any other information exchanged on the Internet and definitely should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas. However, you believe the government probably should not have the right to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

#### **Trust and Social Interactions**  
Generally, you feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people. You do not trust people you meet for the first time at all and do not trust people you know at all. Friends are rather important in your life, though you never obtain information by talking with friends or colleagues.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You never obtain information from email, mobile phones, the Internet, radio news, or daily newspapers. Instead, you obtain information from TV news daily. You do not have very much confidence in the press, television, or banks.  

#### **Health and Well-being**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as good.  

#### **Final Thoughts on Society and Governance**  
Your opinion about society is that our present society must be valiantly defended against all subversive forces. You believe making sure this country has strong defense forces should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years, followed by trying to make our cities and countryside more beautiful. Progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important to you.  

You strongly believe in the importance of democracy, freedom, and individual rights, yet you also hold deep convictions about religious authority and social order. Your life is shaped by faith, family, and a strong work ethic, with a cautious but firm stance on national security and governance.

You agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and strongly believe in greater incentives for individual effort. You also strongly believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves.  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
You belong to the Muslim denomination, and religion is rather important in your life. God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and you pray several times a day. #### **Political Views and Governance**

You think the government should let people come to work as long as there are jobs available. You neither agree nor disagree that when jobs are scarce, employers should prioritize citizens over immigrants.  

You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different race, people who speak a different language, or people with AIDS as neighbors. However, you would not like to have homosexuals, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **International Views and Organizations**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, World Bank, International Monetary Fund, International Criminal Court, North Atlantic Treaty Organization, World Health Organization, and environmental organizations. You believe international organizations should strongly prioritize being democratic over being effective (level 10).

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from TV news, radio news, and the Internet daily, and from email, daily newspapers, and conversations with friends or colleagues weekly. You do not have much confidence in the press or major companies but have quite a lot of confidence in television and banks.  

#### **Social Values and Priorities**  
Friends are very important in your life, as is leisure time. You consider hard work, independence, and responsibility important qualities for children to learn but do not value good manners, imagination, or religious faith as much.  

You strongly disagree that when a mother works, the children suffer. You neither agree nor disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it causes problems. You agree that, on the whole, men make better business executives than women but also that women are less corrupt than men. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often.  

#### **Future Goals and National Priorities**  
You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country, followed by making cities and countryside more beautiful. Maintaining order in the nation is most important, while the fight against crime is second.  

You are willing to fight for your country if there were a war, and you are very worried about a war involving your country. You are also very worried about a terrorist attack.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life (level 10) and describe yourself as rather happy. You feel very close to your village, town, or city; your county, region, or district; and your continent. You are very proud of your country’s nationality and believe living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10).  

You trust people you know personally somewhat but do not trust people you meet for the first time very much. Generally, you believe you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You believe the world is a lot better off because of science and technology (level 10) and think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technological development.  

You always vote in national elections but would never sign a petition, join a boycott or strike, attend a peaceful demonstration, encourage political action, or contact a government official.  

This is your story—rooted in faith, family, and a strong sense of security, with a cautious but hopeful outlook on the world.

You were born in this country in the year 1966, making you 52 years old. You are male, currently married, and the chief wage earner in your household. Your spouse belongs to the clerical group (e.g., secretary, clerk, office manager, civil servant, bookkeeper) and has completed upper secondary education. Together, you live in a household of four people, including yourself, and you do not live with your parents or in-laws. You have three children, and family is very important in your life.  

Your father was born in country 818 and belonged to the unskilled worker group (e.g., laborer, porter, unskilled factory worker, cleaner). Your mother was born in this country, and both your parents were born in country 818. You strongly agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. Comparing your standard of living with your parents' when they were about your age, you would say that you are better off.  

#### **Religion and Beliefs**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Muslim denomination. God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and you pray several times a day. You attend religious services more than once a week. You believe in heaven, hell, and life after death. You agree that religion is right when it conflicts with science, though you neither agree nor disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies instead of to do good to other people. You consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn. You do not belong to any church or religious organization, but you have quite a lot of confidence in the churches.  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
Work is very important in your life, and you are employed full-time (30 hours a week or more). You strongly agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time, and that work is a duty towards society. You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You strongly believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class and belong to the seventh highest income group in your country. Your family saved money during the past year, and you or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months.  

You somewhat believe that incomes should be made more equal, with some support for individual incentives (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You largely believe that government should take more responsibility to ensure that everyone is provided for, with minimal emphasis on individual responsibility (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You moderately believe that private ownership of business and industry should be increased, with limited support for government ownership (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are not very interested in politics and are not a member of any political party. You never discuss political matters with your friends and would never encourage others to vote, though you usually vote in national elections. You believe votes are counted fairly fairly often in this country's elections, and you believe voters are offered a genuine choice fairly often. However, you also believe opposition candidates are prevented from running fairly often.  

You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, and you believe living in a country that is governed democratically is of somewhat high importance to you (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You believe your country is moderately democratic in how it is being governed today (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You also feel it would be fairly good to have a system governed by religious law in which there are no political parties or elections.  

You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and you agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders and business executives than women do. However, you disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl, and you believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often in this country.  

#### **Immigration and Foreign Policy**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come. You agree that immigration increases the crime rate and leads to social conflict, but you also agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, and offers people from poor countries a better life. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants.  

You find it hard to say whether immigration provides asylum to political refugees, but you believe immigrants have a quite good impact on the development of your country.  

#### **Security and Crime**  
You feel very secure these days. You or your family never felt unsafe from crime in your home in the last 12 months, and no one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year. You have not avoided carrying money for security reasons or avoided going out at night for security reasons.  

In your neighborhood, racist behavior does not occur at all, robberies do not occur at all, and alcohol consumption in the streets does not occur at all. However, drug sales and street violence and fights occur quite frequently.  

#### **Trust and Confidence in Institutions**  
You have no confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the United Nations, the World Health Organization, the International Monetary Fund, the International Criminal Court, the press, or television at all. You do not have very much confidence in parliament, major companies, or universities.  

However, you have quite a lot of confidence in environmental organizations, the civil service, banks, and charitable or humanitarian organizations.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You believe political violence, stealing property, violence against other people, terrorism, euthanasia, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, and avoiding a fare on public transport are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe a man beating his wife is usually not justified (level 4 on a scale of 1-10), and parents beating children is somewhat not justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is rarely justified (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You somewhat disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Social and Community Life**  
Friends are very important in your life, and you trust people you know personally completely. You trust people you meet for the first time somewhat but do not trust people of another nationality very much. You trust people of another religion somewhat and do not mind having people of a different religion or race as neighbors. However, you would not like to have homosexuals, people who have AIDS, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people who speak a different language as neighbors.  

You are not a member of any political party, women’s group, professional association, labor union, art/music/educational organization, sport/recreational organization, self-help/mutual aid group, or humanitarian/charitable organization.  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You never obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the Internet, radio news, a daily newspaper, or by talking with friends or colleagues. However, you obtain information from TV news daily.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. Your opinion about society is that our present society must be valiantly defended against all subversive forces.  

You feel very close to your village, town, or city; your county, region, or district; and your continent. You are quite proud to be of your country's nationality. Of course, we all hope that there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.

#### **Security and Crime**  
You feel very secure these days. No one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year, and you or your family never felt unsafe from crime at home. #### **Moral and Ethical Stances**

- Stealing property.  
- A man beating his wife.  
- Parents beating children.

- Violence against other people.  
- Prostitution.  
- Cheating on taxes.  
- Claiming government benefits fraudulently.  
- Avoiding a fare on public transport.  
- Accepting a bribe.

- Homosexuality.  
- Divorce.

#### **Gender and Equality**  
You strongly disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it causes problems. You strongly disagree that men make better business executives than women. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often.  

However, you strongly agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer. You also agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.  

#### **Science, Technology, and Progress**  
You completely agree that science and technology make our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 10). You think the world is a lot better off because of them (level 10). You completely disagree that knowing about science is unimportant in daily life (level 1).  

You slightly disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 4). You think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development.  

#### **Future Goals and Priorities**  
You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years. In your opinion, a stable economy is most important, followed by progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society and making cities and countryside more beautiful.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10). Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. You describe your state of health these days as good.  

You trust your neighborhood somewhat and people you know personally somewhat, but not those you meet for the first time. Friends are rather important in your life, and you occasionally discuss political matters with them.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You believe in both hard work and luck/connections for success, with a slight emphasis on hard work (level 5). If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would pick equality; if between freedom and security, you would pick security.  

You live a life shaped by strong moral convictions, a deep belief in democracy’s ideals (even if not realized in your country), and a commitment to family, work, and societal duty.

You place your political views at position 5 on the left-right scale (center position).  

You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system in this country and believe living in a democratically governed country is of high importance to you (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You believe your country is moderately democratic today (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that work is a duty towards society. You also strongly agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time.  

You believe in several essential characteristics of democracy:  
- People receiving state aid for unemployment (level 10).  
- Civil rights protecting people from state oppression (level 10).  
- Governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor (level 10).  
- People obeying their rulers (level 10).  
- Women having the same rights as men (level 10).  
- People choosing their leaders in free elections (level 10).  

You believe votes are counted fairly very often in this country’s elections, voters are offered a genuine choice fairly often, and election officials are fair fairly often. You also believe opposition candidates are not at all often prevented from running, and voters are not at all often threatened with violence at the polls. However, you think TV news favors the governing party fairly often, and journalists do not often provide fair coverage of elections.  

#### **Economic and Security Concerns**  
You believe fighting rising prices is most important for the country, followed by a stable economy. You strongly believe that competition is good (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and moderately believe that hard work usually brings a better life (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women, but you strongly disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl.  

You have avoided carrying much money and going out at night for security reasons. You or your family often felt unsafe from crime in your home in the last 12 months, and robberies occur quite frequently in your neighborhood. However, no one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year, and you have not been a victim either.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come here to work. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants. You agree that immigration increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, and increases the crime rate. However, you also agree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees and offers people from poor countries a better life. You find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies.  

You do not trust people of another religion at all and do not trust people of another nationality very much. However, you do not mind having people of a different religion, race, or language as neighbors. You also do not mind having unmarried couples, homosexuals, or heavy drinkers as neighbors, but you would not like to have people with AIDS or drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Trust and Confidence in Institutions**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in:  
- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization.  
- The World Bank.  
- The United Nations.  
- Environmental organizations.  
- The civil service.  
- The government.  
- Parliament.  
- The armed forces.  
- The courts.  
- The police.  
- Universities.  
- Major companies.  
- The World Health Organization.  

You have a great deal of confidence in churches and charitable or humanitarian organizations. However, you have no confidence in television or the International Monetary Fund at all and do not have very much confidence in banks or the press.  

#### **Views on Violence, Justice, and Social Issues**  
You believe political violence is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), as is violence against other people, stealing property, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to, avoiding fares on public transport, prostitution, homosexuality, sex before marriage, casual sex, divorce (almost never, level 2), euthanasia, terrorism, parents beating children, and a man beating his wife.  

You strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples. You neither agree nor disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems (level 5).  

#### **Lifestyle and Media Habits**  
You obtain information from TV news daily but never from a daily newspaper or mobile phone. You get information from radio news less than monthly and by talking with friends or colleagues monthly. Leisure time is not very important in your life, and you would never attend a peaceful demonstration, sign a petition, join a strike, or contact a government official.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are completely dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and would say you are not at all happy. Your state of health these days is very poor. You feel quite secure these days but generally believe you need to be very careful in dealing with people. You trust your neighborhood somewhat and people you know personally somewhat, but not people you meet for the first time very much.  

You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel very close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district, but not very close to your continent. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to other people.  

Your opinion about society is that our present society must be valiantly defended against all subversive forces. You believe progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is the second most important goal, after making our cities and countryside more beautiful.  

You strongly agree that it is a duty towards society to have children and that adult children have the duty to provide long-term care for their parents. You consider hard work an important quality for children to learn.  

In the end, if you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider freedom more important. But if you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important.

### **Your Comprehensive Backstory**  

#### **Personal Background and Family Life**  
You were born in this country in the year 1995, making you 25 years old. You are male, currently single, and have no children. You live regularly in a household of four people, including yourself, and reside with your own parent(s). Your father was born in country 417, while your mother was born in this country. Both of your parents were highly educated—your mother holds a Master's degree or equivalent, and your father belonged to the professional and technical group (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse).  

Family is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud. You and your family never went without enough food, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months, though your family just got by financially over the past year. Comparing your standard of living to your parents’ at your age, you believe you are better off.  

#### **Religious Beliefs and Values**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Muslim denomination. You attend religious services more than once a week, pray several times a day, and believe in God, whom you consider very important (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one and do not trust people of another religion at all. You also believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to other people.  

You strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You completely agree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 10 on a scale of 1-10) and that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). However, you believe the world is a lot better off because of science and technology (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political Views and Governance**  
You are not at all interested in politics and are not a member of any political party. If there were a national election tomorrow, you would vote for another party, though you never vote in national elections. You have no confidence in parliament, the press, television, the armed forces, the International Monetary Fund, or the courts at all. However, you have a great deal of confidence in the government, environmental organizations, and universities, as well as quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, the World Bank, the World Health Organization, and the International Criminal Court.  

You feel it would be very bad to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country and believe your country is minimally democratic in how it is governed today (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). Instead, you feel it would be fairly good to have a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections and would prefer a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. You strongly believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe in some democratic principles, such as people choosing their leaders in free elections, civil rights protecting people from state oppression, governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor, and people receiving state aid for unemployment—all of which you consider absolutely essential characteristics of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). However, you also believe that religious authorities should ultimately interpret the laws and that people should obey their rulers (level 10). You do not believe the army taking over when the government is incompetent is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 1).  

#### **Social and Economic Perspectives**  
You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and the middle income group in your country. Work is rather important in your life, and you strongly agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. However, you strongly disagree that work is a duty towards society. You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that there should be greater incentives for individual effort (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe in competition (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) but also strongly believe that hard work doesn’t generally bring success—it’s more a matter of luck and connections (level 10). You think it would be a good thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreign Relations**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let anyone come who wants to. You agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity, offers people from poor countries a better life, and provides asylum to political refugees. However, you disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies or increases the crime rate, though you agree it leads to social conflict and increases unemployment. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants.  

You have no confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at all but trust people of another nationality completely. You feel very close to your continent, county, region, or district, and village, town, or city.  

#### **Security, Crime, and Justice**  
You feel very secure these days and have not been the victim of a crime in the past year, nor has anyone in your family. You have not avoided carrying money or going out at night for security reasons. Police or military interference with private life occurs quite frequently in your neighborhood, and street violence and fights also occur quite frequently. However, robberies, alcohol consumption, drug sales, and racist behavior do not occur frequently in your neighborhood.  

You have no confidence in the police and believe most civil service providers are involved in corruption, though you think few business executives and journalists are corrupt. You strongly believe that political violence, stealing property, beating one’s wife, having casual sex, prostitution, homosexuality, cheating on taxes, claiming government benefits fraudulently, accepting bribes, and avoiding public transport fares are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). However, you believe euthanasia and parents beating children are always justified (level 10).  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from TV news daily and the Internet daily but never from email or your mobile phone. You obtain information by talking with friends or colleagues weekly and from a daily newspaper less than monthly. You have no confidence in the press or television at all and believe TV news favors the governing party very often in elections.  

#### **Social and Moral Values**  
You strongly agree that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents. You consider good manners, a feeling of responsibility, and religious faith important qualities for children to learn but do not value imagination, independence, or hard work as much.  

You strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples and would not like to have homosexuals, people of a different religion, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors. However, you do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different race, or people who speak a different language as neighbors.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10 on a scale of 1-10) and describe your state of health as very good. Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. You strongly disagree that it is a duty towards society to have children and that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You also strongly disagree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer.  

You believe in gradual societal improvement through reforms and think seeing that people have more say about how things are done at their jobs and in their communities should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years. Maintaining order in the nation is most important to you, followed by trying to make cities and countryside more beautiful and ensuring a stable economy.  

You trust people you know personally somewhat but do not trust your neighborhood at all and do not trust people you meet for the first time at all. Generally, you believe you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

This is your life—shaped by faith, family, and firm convictions about how society should function.

All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as poor. Taking all things together, you would say you are not very happy, and all things considered, you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Final Thoughts**

#### **Religion and Morality**

You attend religious services more than once a week and pray several times a day. You disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one.

You agree that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems, and when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. #### **Immigration and National Identity**  
You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel very close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county, region, or district. You also feel close to your continent. #### **Trust and Confidence in Institutions**

#### **Crime and Social Issues in Your Neighborhood**  
Racist behavior, alcohol consumption, robberies, drug sales, and street violence do not occur frequently in your neighborhood. You do not mind having unmarried couples, homosexuals, heavy drinkers, people who have AIDS, or drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are somewhat dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are not very happy. You always vote in national elections and believe having honest elections is very important for you. You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), though living in a democratically governed country is of low importance to you (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).

You find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies or strengthens cultural diversity.

Religion is not at all important in your life, and you do not belong to any religious denomination. However, you very strongly agree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 9). You slightly agree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 6).  

#### **Personal Happiness and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8). Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as good.  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel very close to your continent, county/region/district, and village/town/city. While you are cautious about immigration and prioritize national interests, you also acknowledge some benefits it brings. ### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal Demographics and Family Life**  
You were born in this country in the year 1970, making you 47 years old. You are male, currently divorced, and live regularly in a household with only yourself. You have no children and do not live with your parents or in-laws. Your father was born in country 840, as was your mother, though she was also born in this country. Your father belonged to the skilled worker group (e.g., foreman, motor mechanic, printer, seamstress, tool and die maker, electrician), while your mother completed post-secondary non-tertiary education.  

Family is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud. You or your family never went without enough food, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months, though your family just got by during the past year. Comparing your standard of living with your parents' at your age, you would say you are worse off.  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
You are employed full-time (30 hours a week or more) and are the chief wage earner in your household. You belong to the third lowest income group in your country and describe yourself as working class. Work is rather important in your life, and you agree that work is a duty towards society, though you think it would be good if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time.  

You strongly believe that competition is good and that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life. However, you strongly believe that incomes should be made more equal. You moderately believe that the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You largely support private ownership of business and industry with minimal government ownership (level 2 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political Views and Engagement**  
You place your political views at position 1, the leftmost position on the political spectrum. You are very interested in politics and frequently discuss political matters with your friends. You always vote in national elections and believe votes are counted fairly very often. You have encouraged others to vote and have encouraged people to take political action online. You might sign a petition, attend a peaceful demonstration, or join a strike, and you have signed an electronic petition before. You might also contact a government official or organize political activities online, though you haven’t done so yet.  

You are dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You have no confidence in parliament at all and do not have very much confidence in the government, banks, major companies, or the International Monetary Fund. However, you have quite a lot of confidence in the police, the armed forces, the civil service, and the courts.  

You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system and believe your country is fairly democratic today (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly oppose a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections and reject the idea of a strong leader bypassing parliament and elections. You believe giving people more say in government decisions is most important for the country, followed by seeing people have more say in their jobs and communities.  

#### **Social and Cultural Beliefs**  
You are very proud of your nationality but do not feel very close to your county, region, district, village, town, or city. However, you feel close to your continent.  

You strongly support gender equality, believing women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often. You strongly disagree that men make better political leaders or business executives than women. You also disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it causes problems, or that children suffer when a mother works.  

You strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples and believe homosexuality is always justified. You do not mind having homosexuals, unmarried couples, people of a different race, religion, or language, or even people with AIDS as neighbors. However, you would not like to have drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Religion and Spirituality**  
Religion is not at all important in your life, and you do not belong to any religious denomination, church, or religious organization. You never or practically never pray, and God is not at all important to you. You do not believe in God, heaven, hell, or life after death. You disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science and strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow norms and ceremonies.  

#### **Immigration and International Views**  
You believe immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, and offers people from poor countries a better life, though you also agree it leads to social conflict. You think the government should let people come to work as long as jobs are available and disagree that employers should prioritize citizens over immigrants when jobs are scarce. However, you believe immigrants have a very bad impact on your country’s development. You find it hard to say whether immigration increases unemployment, crime, or provides asylum to political refugees.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in international organizations like the United Nations, the World Bank, the World Health Organization, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and the International Criminal Court. You believe international organizations should slightly prioritize effectiveness over democracy (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Security and Crime**  
You feel very secure these days and have not avoided going out at night or carrying much money for security reasons. No one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year, and you or your family never felt unsafe from crime at home. In your neighborhood, police or military interference with private life, robberies, racist behavior, alcohol consumption, drug sales, and street violence do not occur at all or frequently.  

You believe the government probably should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas but definitely should not monitor all emails and online exchanges. You also believe the government probably should not collect information about anyone without their knowledge.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Stances**  
You consider good manners and a sense of responsibility important qualities for children to learn but do not value hard work, religious faith, imagination, or independence as much.  

You believe political violence, terrorism, violence against others, a man beating his wife, parents beating children, cheating on taxes, and accepting bribes are never justified. You also believe stealing property, fare evasion, and claiming undeserved government benefits are rarely justified. However, you believe casual sex, sex before marriage, divorce, and prostitution are almost always or sometimes justified. You believe euthanasia is sometimes justified (level 7).  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from the Internet daily, radio news weekly, and TV news monthly. You rarely use email, mobile phones, or daily newspapers for information. You also talk with friends or colleagues weekly.  

You have a great deal of confidence in television and quite a lot in the press. You believe TV news does not favor the governing party and that journalists provide fair election coverage very often.  

#### **Science, Technology, and Progress**  
You completely disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith and strongly believe the world is better off because of science and technology. You think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development. You completely agree that science and technology make life healthier, easier, and more comfortable.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life (level 5). You describe your health as good and consider yourself rather happy. Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. If another war came, you would be willing to fight for your country, though you are worried a good deal about the possibility.  

You strongly value freedom over equality and security, believe in democratic principles, and prioritize a stable economy and humane society. You trust people you know personally, your neighborhood, and those of another religion or nationality somewhat. While you have criticisms of your country, you remain engaged, hopeful, and committed to progressive change.

You are employed full-time (30 hours a week or more) and belong to the fourth lowest income group in your country. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class. You agree that people who don’t work turn lazy.  

You somewhat believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves, with some emphasis on government responsibility (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You somewhat believe there should be greater incentives for individual effort, with some support for income equality (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You believe both hard work and luck/connections play important roles in success, with a slight emphasis on luck and connections (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

You have no confidence in major companies at all and believe all business executives are involved in corruption. You have quite a lot of confidence in banks.

You place your political views at position 3 on the left-right scale (leaning moderately left). You are not a member of any political party but are somewhat interested in politics. You believe opposition candidates are not often prevented from running in this country's elections, and voters are not at all often threatened with violence at the polls. You believe having honest elections is very important for you.  

You feel it would be fairly bad to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections as a way of governing this country. You also feel it would be fairly bad to have experts, not government, make decisions according to what they think is best for the country. You strongly disagree with the idea of a system governed by religious law in which there are no political parties or elections.  

You have no confidence in parliament at all and do not have very much confidence in the government. You do not have very much confidence in the civil service and believe most of the civil service providers are involved in corruption. You do not have very much confidence in the police or the armed forces.

You are quite proud to be of your country's nationality. You feel close to your county, region, or district and very close to your village, town, or city, but you do not feel very close to your continent.  

You believe in gradual societal improvement through reforms. You consider independence, imagination, and a feeling of responsibility important qualities for children to learn, but you do not consider hard work, good manners, or religious faith important for them.  

You agree that adult children have the duty to provide long-term care for their parents but disagree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud.
