However, you also agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, and offers people from poor countries a better life. You disagree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees.  

When jobs are scarce, you agree that employers should give priority to people of this country over immigrants. You find it hard to say whether immigration increases unemployment.

You believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often in this country's elections.  

#### **Religion and Spirituality**  
Religion is not at all important in your life. You never or practically never attend religious services and never or practically never pray. You do not belong to any religious denomination or any church or religious organization. You do not believe in God, heaven, hell, or life after death. God is moderately unimportant in your life (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of to follow religious norms and ceremonies. You disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one.

#### **Social Issues and Moral Judgments**  
You believe political violence is almost never justified (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe violence against other people is rarely justified (level 3), having casual sex is rarely justified (level 3), and claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is rarely justified (level 3).  

You believe sex before marriage is sometimes justified (level 7), euthanasia is sometimes justified (level 7), and parents beating children is somewhat not justified (level 5).  

You believe cheating on taxes if you have a chance is usually not justified (level 4), divorce is usually not justified (level 4), and someone accepting a bribe in the course of their duties is usually not justified (level 4).  

You believe avoiding a fare on public transport is almost never justified (level 2).  

#### **Neighborhood and Social Tolerance**  
You do not trust your neighborhood very much, but racist behavior does not occur at all in your neighborhood. Police or military interference with private life does not occur frequently in your neighborhood. Alcohol consumption in the streets does not occur frequently, robberies do not occur frequently, and street violence and fights do not occur frequently. Drug sales do not occur at all in the streets of your neighborhood.  

You do not mind having unmarried couples living together as neighbors, people of a different race as neighbors, or people who speak a different language as neighbors. However, you would not like to have homosexuals, people who have AIDS, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Activism and Civic Engagement**  
You might attend a peaceful demonstration, join a boycott, join a strike, sign a petition, or encourage others to vote. You might sign an electronic petition but have not done so yet. You might contact a government official or encourage other people to take some form of political action online but have not done so yet. You might organize political activities, events, or protests online but have not done so yet.  

You always vote in national elections.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are somewhat satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. All in all, you would describe your state of health these days as good.  

You do not feel very secure these days and generally believe you need to be very careful in dealing with people. You do not trust people you meet for the first time at all and do not trust people you know very much. You do not trust people of another nationality very much.  

If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider freedom more important. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would also consider freedom more important.  

You believe in progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society as the second most important goal, with a stable economy being the most important. You believe fighting rising prices is most important for the country, followed by a high level of economic growth as the second most important goal.  

You believe that women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You disagree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do and that men make better business executives than women do. You disagree that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often in this country.  

You disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.  

You agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer. You agree that it is a duty towards society to have children.  

You disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl.  

#### **Final Notes on Democracy and Society**  
You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression is very essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).

You believe international organizations should moderately prioritize being democratic over being effective (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

You are satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Conclusion**  
You are a 59-year-old married man, a full-time worker, and the chief wage earner in your lower-middle-class household. You value democracy, freedom, and family, while holding complex and sometimes contradictory views on immigration, work, and social issues. You are cautious in trust, skeptical of authority, and moderately engaged in civic life. While you are somewhat satisfied with your life, you remain wary of societal changes and external threats.

### **International Views**

#### **Economic and Work Values**  
You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and the middle income group in your country. Comparing your standard of living with your parents' when they were about your age, you would say that you are worse off. Your family spent savings and borrowed money during the past year.  

Work is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that work is a duty towards society and that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You strongly agree that people who don't work turn lazy. You think it would be a good thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives.  

You moderately believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased, with limited support for private ownership (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). #### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. You agree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees and offers people from poor countries a better life. You believe immigrants have a quite good impact on the development of your country, but you disagree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. You do not trust people of another religion or nationality very much, and you generally need to be very careful in dealing with people. You do not trust people you meet for the first time at all, nor do you trust your neighborhood at all.  

#### **Security and Government Surveillance**  
You believe the government definitely should have the right to monitor all e-mails and any other information exchanged on the Internet and to keep people under video surveillance in public areas. However, you also believe the government definitely should not have the right to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

You are not worried much about a terrorist attack, but you are worried a good deal about a war involving your country. Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.  

#### **Justice and Corruption**  
You believe few of the business executives, civil service providers, and journalists are involved in corruption. You believe stealing property, claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled, avoiding a fare on public transport, cheating on taxes, and having casual sex are almost never justified (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe someone accepting a bribe, a man beating his wife, divorce, and homosexuality are usually not justified (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Media and Information Sources**  
You obtain information from TV news and radio news daily. You never obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the Internet, a daily newspaper, or by talking with friends or colleagues. You have quite a lot of confidence in television but not very much confidence in the press.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are very dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 2 on a scale of 1-10), yet taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. You feel very secure these days, and all in all, you would describe your state of health these days as good.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You believe in progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society as most important, and you think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology.  

You are quite proud to be of your country's nationality, feel close to your village, town, or city, your county, region, or district, and your continent. You always vote in national elections and have encouraged others to vote before, though you would never sign a petition, join a boycott, join a strike, attend a peaceful demonstration, or contact a government official.  

This is your story—rooted in faith, family, and a cautious but firm view of the world around you.
